TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Last Wednesday the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) asked me to consider the possible application of standing order 85 to Question Time and I undertook to look into the matter. Standing order 85 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Speaker, or the Chairman, after having called the attention of the House, or of the committee, to the conduct of a Member, who persists in irrelevance, or tedious repetition either of his own arguments, or of the arguments used by other Members in debate, may direct him to discontinue his speech: Provided that such Member shall have the right to require that the question whether he be further heard be put, and thereupon such question shall be put without debate.

Members will note that the standing order refers to debate and a member's speech. The records of the House reveal that this rule has been applied only to debates, never to answers to questions. Where the meaning and application of the rule is explained in House of Representatives Practice, at page 456, there is no mention of answers to questions.

Chapter XI of the Standing Orders contains detailed provisions in respect of questions and some provisions in respect of answers, and provides the main rules. But it must be acknowledged that the Standing Orders in chapter XI do not provide a complete statement of all the rules governing Question Time. For example, the sub judice rule applies but it is not mentioned in the chapter. In addition, there is no mention in the chapter of the rule on interjections, yet it is only sensible to read that rule as having general application. I also note that at page 488 of House of Representatives Practice it is recorded that the content of questions must comply with the general rules governing the content of speeches. This statement is also to be found in May's Parliamentary Practice; there is no mention of answers.

I also remind members of the final provision in standing order 85 to the effect that, if the Chair directs a member to discontinue his speech, the member has the right to require that the question of whether he be further heard be put, and this question must be put without debate. I would be surprised if members wished to have such a right enshrined in so far as Question Time is concerned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) asked me whether it was correct to say that Question Time was a privilege extended by the Executive. The honourable member quoted from House of Representatives Practice on the accountability of the Executive to the Parliament and on the importance of questions on notice and questions without notice in so far as the capacity of the House to call the Government to account is concerned. I am sure all members would agree that Question Time is an important practical, as well as symbolic, manifestation of the constitutional relationship between the House and the Executive.

INTERJECT.PARA: Despite its importance, the period's status in technical terms is, in a sense, and has always been slightly tenuous. Whilst standing order 142 states that `questions may be put to a Minister' and so on, and standing order 101 provides for questions without notice in the routine of business, members will be aware that the duration of question time is traditionally a matter for the Government to determine. It is also established practice that Ministers cannot be compelled to answer questions.

I note that it was not until the adoption of permanent Standing Orders in 1950 that questions without notice were included in the standing order governing the routine of business. This is despite the fact that questions featured in proceedings from the first Parliament. It illustrates, I think, that, in a procedural sense, Question Time had a slightly unofficial but conventional standing. Despite these considerations, the question period, to my knowledge, has always been regarded by honourable members as a vitally important proceeding of the House. It has the well-known function, mentioned by the honourable member, of enabling the Executive to be called to account. I would commend to all honourable members a reading of pages 479 to 482 of House of Representatives Practice, which give a short history of questions and Question Time. We might all reflect on the situation we have arrived at over recent years, and perhaps ask ourselves whether Question Time does not warrant a more businesslike and less confrontational approach with regard to both questions and answers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Treasurer by reminding him that I have yet to receive an answer to a question taken on notice by the Acting Treasurer on 13 October 1988 concerning the after-tax real rate of return on savings deposits. In the meantime, I ask the Treasurer whether he estimates that a rise in mortgage rates to 15.5 per cent would reduce the number of new housing starts by approximately 20 per cent. If not, what is the Treasurer's estimate of the impact of a rise in mortgage rates to 15.5 per cent on the number of new housing starts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only observe that, in terms of empirical evidence, we now have the strongest level of housing starts in our history-that is, nearly 160,000 from a base of 105,000 which existed in the last year of the coalition Government to which the questioner belonged. That has been accommodated in part by the deregulation of the savings bank system which the Government to which the honourable member belonged did not have either the interest or the courage to do. That flow of funds to the housing sector from a proper working and functioning of the banking system has allowed this level of housing starts and, for the first time in its history, the Australian housing industry is not facing the kinds of changes in prosperity that it once faced, given the fact that banks can take deposits, buy deposits off the market and lend them at a commercial price-that is, lend them outside the area of regulation. That guarantees a flow of funds to the banking system which it has not had before.

ANSWER.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party asked me whether an increase in housing interest rates would have a certain effect on the number of loans advanced and housing starts. The capacity of the industry to build houses is a finite one. Regardless of the level of housing approvals, what we would see otherwise would be the industry bumping up against the capacity constraints which both labour and material supply impact upon that industry. Were that not the case, that demand would simply spill over into prices. If it spills over into prices there is less advantage to people seeking a home loan, particularly for a first home, or, more generally, housing accommodation. I can only observe that, regardless of the implication and point of the honourable gentleman's question, we are now building houses in this country at a rate faster than ever before while running up against capacity constraints.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Following the unfortunate incident at the Yugoslav Consulate in Sydney over the weekend where a teenage demonstrator was shot by a security guard, will the Government ensure that the matter will be investigated fully and that the person or persons responsible will be dealt with according to Australian law? Will the Government remind our ethnic communities that, as Australians, their responsibility is, first and foremost, to Australia and not to events which occur in other parts of the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hotham for his question. I can say to him that the Government views the shooting of Josef Tokic at the Yugoslav Consulate-General in Sydney on the weekend as intolerable and totally unacceptable. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has made it clear to the Yugoslav Ambassador, Dr Cizelj, and to the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry in Belgrade, that this Government expects complete cooperation from the Embassy and from the Consulate-General in dealing with this matter. We do not believe that this is a matter for which any reliance on immunity in any form is appropriate.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has said, and I am sure that honourable members would agree, that he expects that the law in this case will follow the normal course. The Yugoslav authorities have confirmed today, in response to our representations, that they will cooperate by, firstly, making the person concerned available for interview by the New South Wales police; secondly, handing over the firearm; and, thirdly, ensuring that the person involved would not seek to leave Australia before the matter is dealt with. The Government accepts fully its responsibility to protect the personnel and premises of diplomatic and consular offices in Australia. I have noted the claim that security provided at the Consultate-General yesterday afternoon was inadequate. We are examining this aspect. I emphasise that whatever the provocation involved in the intrusion on the Consulate grounds and the attempt to pull down the Yugoslav flag, the use of firearms in response is totally indefensible.

Australia is a multicultural society and, in it, people have the right to remember with respect and honour their own traditions and cultures. We want them to do that. People in this country also have a right to demonstrate peacefully and to express their views, but any actions must be within the law. As I said on Friday, we do not want to see Australia become a battleground in terms of people trying to live out and act out ancient rivalries that may still, to some extent, bedevil their places of origin. Our policy of multiculturalism presumes an overriding and unifying commitment to Australia in which people see themselves first and foremost as Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the decision of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) to conduct a private hearing into the affairs of Rothwells Ltd and associated companies because of the Commission's belief that `offences that involve fraud or dishonesty . . . may have been committed'. Is there any obligation on the Commission to make public all evidence obtained at the inquiry? If not, in the interests of the fullest public disclosure of this financial scandal-and the major role played by the Burke and Dowding governments-will the Attorney take the initiative at this Thursday's meeting of the State and Federal Attorneys to direct a special investigation? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable gentleman would know, Rothwells is incorporated in Queensland and, of course, any encouragement for a special investigation certainly would be moved by the Attorney-General for Queensland. An order has been made in the Queensland Supreme Court to appoint a liquidator. According to the reports that I have read, obviously he will be making some report in the second week of December.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member asks whether the NCSC has made any recommendation in this matter to the Ministerial Council. It has not done so. Of course, I am anxious that it will be able to tell us something about it when the meeting takes place on Thursday of this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your initiative?
—As the honourable member knows, because of the scheme being the way it is-which the coalition took credit in designing--
—You have all the powers.

—No; not all the powers, at all. We would be involved only in the case of some special national proposition that the Ministerial Council felt could not he handled. For the life of me, at one point the honourable member represents Queensland and the Queensland Attorney-General has not raised the issue; at another point he represents the National Companies and Securities Commission, which has never raised the matter. So, apparently, because the Attorney-General in Queensland does not do his job or, apparently, according to the honourable member's records, the National Companies and Securities Commission does not do its job, it is time that the Federal Government did something about national companies. I will do it by bringing in Federal law. We will then have some chance of some accountability. It is no good honourable members opposite waffling on about the need for something to be done. There was an obligation for this Parliament to do something about it by acknowledging that this Parliament has some accountability and some legal statutory basis. We do not have the power to act in the sense that honourable members opposite think we have. That power could only be used if the Ministerial Council felt it should be. It has never been in that position. I am just as anxious as honourable members opposite to get a report from the National Companies and Securities Commission, which at the present time is saying-this is quite understandable-that the matter is still under investigation. The National Companies and Securities Commission has some evidence which obviously will be given to the Attorneys-General when they meet on Thursday. Whilst ever we persevere with the scheme on the basis of its having no national accountability, no parliamentary accountability, no parliamentary scrutiny, is it any wonder that the honourable gentleman is dismayed with the sorts of answers he now gets?

—Let me say these things very simply and directly: first, I have made it clear in public statements that the statements attributed to Mr Egerton are defamatory and untrue.
—Sir John.

—Well, yes, he is Sir John. The statements are still defamatory and untrue. The fact that he is a knight does not make them less defamatory or less untrue. Secondly, as I have indicated, I have instituted legal proceedings which have been issued this morning. Therefore, it is inappropriate to say anything on that.
—I will restrain myself from making the sorts of observations about this collection of ratbags opposite that they deserve. I have repeated--
—Order! Those on my right will come to order.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. I suggest that the Prime Minister might be requested to withdraw that word. It is unseemly and inappropriate.
—The Prime Ministerial will withdraw.
—I will withdraw it. I regard it as inadequate; so I withdraw it.

—I have withdrawn it without qualification. Those who have listened to me here have heard me say that the statements are defamatory and untrue. Having said that, I have then said that legal proceedings have been initiated and it is inappropriate to say anything more. That produced this roar of stupid laughter from those opposite, having said that they are untrue and that they are defamatory. I simply want to make this point: if the honourable gentleman who asked the question would like to make any statement at all outside the privilege of this place that he uses as his coward's castle, I will accommodate him in the courts as well.

—Can the Attorney-General advise the House whether the Government's legislation to provide fair trials to those accused of committing war crimes poses any threat to Australian ex-service men and women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for the question. It is certainly appropriate to reiterate that there are no charges, no allegations at all, of war criminal activity against any Australian ex-service man or woman, particularly relating to the Second World War, to which the legislation refers. I might say that a fair amount of concern has been created amongst the ex-servicemen of Australia by an Opposition suggestion that an amendment needs to be carried to ensure that those allegedly guilty of any misconduct would be exempt. The Government cannot accept that sort of situation. I might add that this legislation was sent to the Senate in November of last year and has been the subject of an inquiry by a Senate committee, which reported in February, but we still have not been able to get the Bill debated in the Senate.
—Bring it on.

—We are very anxious to bring it on, but I understand the appropriations debate is going to take the whole of the week. That is a matter for the Senate. I notice that honourable members opposite are speechless when I say that.
—Are you going to bring it on this week?
—It would be of interest to my constitutional friends opposite that the Senate spends so much time on Estimates committees and the appropriations when it has no power to amend or reject a money Bill.
—Are you going to put it through this year?
—Order!
—I wanted to put it through earlier this year.
—Are you going to put it through this year?
—Order!

—It is a matter for the Senate. I want it to be brought on and, if we can get the business of the Senate arranged, it will be brought on. I would like members of the Opposition to understand that the suggested amendment that people be excluded because they may be indicted for war crimes--
—No, because they served under Australian military law.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting and heed the Chair.

—No; that is the point. The Canadian legislation makes no such exemption; nor does any other legislation in the world. Nor does the Geneva Convention from the point of view of allowing in the case of grave breaches for any exemption on the basis of nationality. It would have been far better and would have alleviated a lot of the concern of the ex-servicemen if the suggestion was that there had to be this amendment to save them. I make the point that there is not a tittle of evidence or any accusation against any Australian service man or woman. That is where the strength of this legislation lies. To be suggesting in the international sphere that some Australians need to be protected from war crimes does not do anything for the honour and integrity of the armed forces. That is the point and that is the issue.
—Oh!
—Order! The Attorney-General will wait for one moment. The Leader of the Opposition continues to interject and refuses to heed the Chair. I suggest he now cease his interjections.

—The Government is most anxious to bring this legislation into place because a number of allegations have been made, investigations have taken place, and if matters are to be pursued in terms of the Director of Public Prosecutions at least it would allow for a fair trial under Australian conditions; that is, a trial by way of committal proceedings and also a trial by way of an Australian jury in a Supreme Court of the relevant State. I think that then would be guaranteeing the world that Australia is fulfilling its obligations under the Geneva Convention. It goes right back to the issues of what are called crimes committed in war. The issues we are now facing are of allegations of the extermination of innocent men, women and children in concentration camps in Europe. They were allegedly committed during the Second World War. Again allegedly, people escaped from Europe and came here. That is the intent of the investigations. That is the reason for the legislation. It is a shame that side issues have been dragged in on the basis that there might be some guilt associated with Australian ex-service men and women.

ANSWER.PARA: I reiterate: there is not a tittle of evidence; nor will there ever be. It is on that basis then that the honourable member should understand that Australians have nothing to fear-nothing at all. To suggest that we have to pass legislation in case something happens would make us the laughing stock of the world. No other country has done it. Canada has not done it. The Europeans do not do it. The issue is that we might be assisting people because we are not favouring extradition, as the Americans do. The Americans extradite these people; I do not see the Opposition suggesting that at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister advise the House on the progress of the Child Support Agency in assuming responsibility for the collection of maintenance payments throughout Australia? What impact will the actual receipt of maintenance payments have on the living standards of children in the estimated 70 per cent of sole parent families previously legally entitled to maintenance but not actually receiving any payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think honourable members will recall that there are three aspects of the child support scheme: the changes to the Family Law Act to improve the level of maintenance; the introduction of the agency to collect maintenance liabilities; and the changes to the way maintenance is assessed in the social security system. Stage one is working quite well. The courts, as I understand it, are now beginning to award rather more realistic levels of maintenance.

ANSWER.PARA: The Agency, as of last Friday, had received more than 12,000 applications for collection of maintenance, benefiting nearly 17,000 children. A significant proportion of those orders was made before the start of the scheme where the liable parent had persistently failed to pay. To date, the Child Support Agency has been unable to locate only 64 out of nearly 9,000 non-custodial parents who are the subject of register order arguments with the Agency. In the period from late June to 17 September the number of sole parent beneficiaries fell while the number with maintenance income increased from 63,095 to 69,994, and the average amount of maintenance for each of these sole parents increased.

In summary, there is an emerging pattern of more adequate levels of maintenance, more effective collection of maintenance, leading to sole parent families being better off, and better coverage of the pensioner population leading to a reduction in outlays on sole parent pensions. May I say in addition that the automatic deduction from salaries and wages began as of 1 November, and as of 25 November the Tax Office had contacted some 300 employers about maintenance deductions from salaries or wages.

This scheme is a complex one. It involves several agencies of the Government. It represents a quite fundamental change in terms of a national scheme to collect maintenance. It is one that undoubtedly will have its teething problems, but so far we are pleased with the progress that has been achieved towards the objective of ensuring that, along with the family assistance program, we address the issue of child poverty in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister. Does he deny attending a luncheon on Wednesday, 16 April 1980, with members of the Gold Coast City Council Health and Planning Committee at Mr Eddie Kornhauser's private quarters in the old Surfers Paradise Hotel? Specifically, does he deny the assertion by former Alderman Betty Diamond that the Prime Minister listened to these discussions, made it clear that he would like to see the Council agree to Mr Kornhauser's request with respect to the development of the Paradise Centre on the Gold Coast and, specifically, that at one stage said that the Council should `look after Eddie'?

—For reasons which I would have thought were obvious to every member of the House, I repeat the answer I previously gave: I have been advised, for obvious reasons, to make no comments on an issue which is now the subject of litigation.

—I address my question to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. The Government has recently received a report from the Cement Industry Tripartite Committee which was established by the Government to identify impediments to improving the competitiveness of the Australian cement industry. Can the Minister inform the House of the major findings of the report and the steps the Government is taking to address the recommendations of the report?

—The Cement Industry Tripartite Committee's report was forwarded to the Government last week and was released publicly on 22 November. The Committee conducted its deliberations in parallel with but independent of two anti-dumping investigations of the industry by the Australian Customs Service and the Bureau of Industry Economics. Submissions were also provided by State governments, and other interested parties were consulted by the Committee. The Committee believes that the Australian cement industry is fundamentally healthy. However, the report suggests that the recent competition from imports has created some uncertainties in the industry. The report, therefore, makes a number of recommendations which it suggests both State and Commonwealth governments should address to ensure that the industry is in a position to meet competition from fairly priced imports. My colleague Senator Button has already written to State and Territory governments informing them of the reports and asking them to consider the recommendations that fall within their responsibilities. The Commonwealth Government will address the issues relevant to its responsibilities and Senator Button has already written to the appropriate Ministers. I want to add that the Committee members devoted considerable time and energy to their preparation of the report. They are to be congratulated on their efforts and the cooperative spirit in which they approached the difficult task with which they were confronted.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support and it refers to the disappearance of the vessel Pantenella off the New South Wales coastline and reported missing on or around 19 November. Is the Minister satisfied that everything possible has been done to locate the boat with four occupants aboard, including two young men from Taree in my electorate? Also, can the Minister say whether there are any suspicious circumstances involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering this question, I first acknowledge the immediate response which the honourable member for Lyne made to this matter when it was brought to his attention, and the speed and the concern that he showed in his inquiries. I believe sufficient has been done in connection with the loss of that schooner, in the light of the information which was available to the Sea Safety Centre. I think the honourable member for Lyne is aware of the fact that the ship sailed from Portland on about the third of the month. The last that was heard of it was on the eighth, when it indicated to the OTC Sydney coast radio station that it was tacking to seaward outside the heads of Sydney and that it intended to come back into Sydney Harbour the next day to refuel and pick up supplies. Nothing else was heard of it. It was not until the nineteenth of the month that any concern was expressed to the Sea Safety Centre regarding any fears that may have been held for that craft. The Sea Safety Centre immediately brought it to the attention of other craft in the area and, as well as that, to aircraft that would have been flying over that area.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty is that a period of about 11 days had elapsed between the time it was last heard from and the time that any concern was expressed. I understand that during that period the area in which the Sea Safety Centre would have been required to man a search would have been something like 200,000 square kilometres and have involved about 120 aircraft. That would have been an impossible task. I think that that places in perspective the difficulty that the Sea Safety Centre had.

I think the Sea Safety Centre did all that it could. In the light of the experience and professionalism of the people at the Sea Safety Centre, it was decided that nothing further could be done. It was interesting though that on Friday-I know that this was one of the things that precipitated the honourable member making inquiries about it as well-one of our Royal Australian Navy submarines indicated that it had seen a flare off Kiama on the east coast of Australia. The Sea Safety Centre pursued that because the only vessel which had been indicated as possibly being lost was the one to which the honourable member has referred. A private plane was chartered to investigate and two vessels which were in the area were advised to keep an eye open for it. I understand that some flotsam was found, but there has been no evidence of any vessel at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Went- worth (Dr Hewson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The crippling tax burden on Australian families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see that again, as I start to speak, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has decided to leave the House rather than take this matter of public importance. It is becoming indicative of the standing of this bloke that every time we ask him a serious question or we offer him the opportunity for serious debate he disappears. He is a man of absolutely no substance when it comes to the economic debate. He is not prepared to put it on the record in here and to chance his arm in a substantial debate. We are seeing all sorts of stunts now as the Treasurer starts to run scared. He does not take questions from us seriously, nor answer them. The only questions he answers are dorothy dixers from his own side. It is getting to the stage where there is one every day. He takes a dorothy dixer to bucket the doctor. There is always a question in the House directed at me, yet he will not get up and debate me. The Treasurer actually introduced that Bill, one of the few Bills he has introduced into this Parliament. He sought in Question Time, on the basis of a dorothy dixer, to try to add to the debate on that Bill, yet when it came to the debate that evening he was nowhere to be seen.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject of today's matter of public importance is the crippling tax burden on Australian families, which is a subject that the Treasurer, more than anyone else, ought to be concerned about, because it is the best barometer we have of the abysmal economic management of this Government. I am staggered that we have not had a tax revolution in this country. The tax burdens that have been imparted on the average Australian in the course of the last four or five years have been absolutely staggering to the point where nearly anybody can identify several aspects of the burden of taxation. Everyone knows how the level of taxation has gone up, but this Government has also significantly increased the complexity of the tax system and compounded the uncertainty associated with the administration of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and now we have a procedure of almost enforcement and harassment by the Commissioner of Taxation to back it up.

The average Australian family has been subject to a very significant increase in the tax burden in all four of those respects. Every Australian will be able to tell you that his standard of living has fallen by the equivalent of about $56 a week. Every Australian will be able to tell you that a tax Act of 3,500 pages is getting beyond the comprehension of most professionals, let alone the average person. Indeed, we have the ludicrous situation in which pensioners are now being forced to hire tax agents to put in fairly basic and simple tax returns. We have this procedure for uncertainty-legislation by announcement. An example of that is the superannuation tax, which was introduced and became effective in July. Yet we read in today's press that perhaps the Bill will be coming into Parliament in the course of this week. But I also read today that it will only partly deal with the issue of superannuation tax-a ludicrous situation. It requires fund managers and superannuation fund owners and participants to act under a law that they yet have no idea about. It will be substantially different to what was announced in the May statement. Yet the Treasurer treats the matter lightly and walks out of the House. Finally, there is increasing evidence that the Tax Commissioner himself is on the warpath. The Treasurer fully supports the kind of ludicrous behaviour we are now seeing in a number of quarters from the Tax Commissioner, as we were told by him, in interpreting the law in a particular way.

The Government should be challenged on its record on tax, because it has one of the most abysmal records. This Treasurer goes around, particularly overseas, trying to give the impression, as he did in London recently, that `our first tax package in 1985 comprehensively reformed our personal income tax system'. There is no reform whatsoever. He paints these fictional pictures when he goes offshore, yet when he is in the House he is not prepared to take a debate on that record. The record speaks for itself. Tax as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP), the measure he should use, is at 25.7 per cent in 1988-89, which equals the peacetime record achieved last year. That compares with average ratios of 19.9 per cent in the 1950s, 18.6 per cent in the 1960s and 20.8 per cent in the 1970s. That is 25.7 per cent of GDP. He does not face up to that number. He prefers to use numbers such as total government revenue to GDP which include such things as profits from the Reserve Bank of Australia. When he runs down the take from the Reserve Bank, he makes that number look better. That is the sort of innovative accounting that this Treasurer prefers to base his record on. He is never prepared to face the sort of objective criteria that anyone else would list.

We have a situation now in which many families on average earnings have seen their tax take increased by about 90 per cent since March 1983. The marginal tax rate for most low to middle income taxpayers is now 40 per cent-it was 30 per cent in 1983-and nearly 50 per cent of all taxpayers face a marginal tax rate of 40 per cent or more. Moreover, the average tax rate has now gone up to 21.6 per cent compared to 17.5 per cent in 1983. Over and above that, the Government has abolished rebates on concessional expenditure, health insurance and housing interest. The dependent spouse rebate has been reduced by 25 per cent in real terms. Family allowances have been frozen since March 1983. So that has been significantly eroded in real terms. Single income families have been about the hardest hit under this Government.

A recent study by the Economic Planning Advisory Council, which the House has had its attention drawn to on several occasions, reveals the extent of some of the `poverty trap' problems being caused by the interaction of this Government's so-called tax reform policies and social security policies. Some families in this country, on 75 per cent of average weekly earnings, faced an effective marginal tax rate of about 90 per cent last year compared with 30 per cent in 1982-83. Yet this Treasurer now has the hide to stand up and suggest that this kind of taxation burden does not sap incentive, that it does not reduce the inclination of Australian families to work to increase their income and advance themselves and so on. Of course it does. It is precisely the wrong sort of tax system for a country like Australia.

The key point in terms of personal tax revenue has been that most of it has been collected in recent days through inflation. Despite the Government's tax cuts in 1986-87, by the end of this financial year it will have increased tax through `bracket creep' by nearly $10 billion. If tax scales had been indexed from 1986-87 onwards, $10 billion less would have been collected by this Government. It has collected $10 billion alone through bracket creep. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) the Treasurer and others have spent a lot of time trying to paint over that picture and ignore it. The Prime Minister was reported in the Australian Financial Review in August of this year as saying that Budget revenue forms a lower share of GDP this year than last year. But he is using those fudged statistics again. He is throwing in other forms of government non-tax revenue. Government tax revenue as a proportion of GDP is exactly the same as it was last year-a historical high.

Apart from these grounds, one can list a lot of new taxes that this Government has introduced: fringe benefits taxes; capital gains taxes; entertainment taxes; the initial removal of negative gearing provisions, which have since been restored; the original foreign tax credit system, which has since been modified; the original lump sum superannuation tax, which has since been partially removed but is still there in essence; increased company tax; new wholesale sales taxes; increased petrol excise from 6c to 20c per litre; automatic biannual indexation of produce excise rates; a wine tax; an excise tax on intermediate and new oil; the tax on superannuation fund income; the gold tax; the graduate tax and so on. This is a staggering number of taxes and tax increases over the life of this Government. No Australian family is in any doubt as to the magnitude of the burden of increased taxation experienced under the Hawke-Keating Government.

Yet, as economic circumstances in recent days have deteriorated, a number of key Government spokesmen have been at pains to convince people that they will deliver tax cuts from 1 July next year. They are now saying on a regular basis that we should not be in any doubt that they will deliver tax cuts from 1 July next year. Even though economic circumstances seem to be slipping through their fingers, it is interesting to note the way that they are staying with that particular commitment. One of the answers is attributable to an explanation given by the Treasurer at the time of the May statement when he was briefing some of his colleagues. He went in to assure them and, as quoted by Geoff Kitney in the Australian Financial Review of 27 May, he stated:
Well, here it is folks. All you people who thought you were going to lose your seats at the next election, this will save you. This will get us back into Government.

Here we are now seeing that his tax cuts are the key element of the forthcoming electoral strategy of this Government. While there is no doubt that that is the case, I think the average Australian should be in no doubt about a number of other things as well. The first of these is that despite the fact that the Government says that the tax cuts are in the bag, it is interesting that it has given no indication as to how big those cuts will be. Honourable members should be in no doubt about the fact that as economic circumstances proceed, as they move against this Government, the magnitude of those tax cuts will be dragged back. The second thing there should be no doubt about is that people will have to give up a wage increase in order to get these tax cuts. The Government is putting a lot of weight on a wage/tax trade-off. The key point is that the only way we will get the promised tax cuts is actually to forgo a wage increase this year and next year.

The third thing there should be no doubt about is that we shall have to live with higher interest rates now in order to get those tax cuts. As the Prime Minister said in a recent press conference, on, I think, 18 November 1988:
We need to manage the Australian economy in a way which is going to ensure that we have the greatest capacity by the middle of next year to bring in sustainable tax cuts.

He then went on to describe how we have to live with tighter monetary policy and higher interest rates now in order to get those tax cuts. Let us look at what that means. Nobody should be in any doubt as to precisely what that means. We should recognise, for example, that a one per cent increase in home mortgage interest rates costs the average Australian who has a $25,000 mortgage about $40 a month. What the Prime Minister is saying is that he will have to pay an extra $40 a month from now on-it is an open-ended sort of statement-in order to get tax cuts from 1 July. It is important to recognise the following point: let us say that the Government gives the $15 per week tax cut from 1 July, which Bill Kelty has been talking about. Do honourable members know how long it would take for them to break even? They would not get in front, matching that increase in house loan interest costs against those tax cuts, until December 1990. So more Australians will really be running behind for the best part of the next 18 months in order to pull out that sort of increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's the Kelty option.
—Yes, the Kelty option.
—That's the one that will happen.

—It is the one that is most likely to happen, as the Leader of the Opposition says. It should also be clear-there should be no doubt on the part of anybody-that people will get only part of what has already been taken in terms of bracket creep. If we do the sums as to how big next year's tax cuts will be, and if we assume that the Government will stay with its commitment of a zero public sector borrowing requirement, the tax cuts next year will not cost much more than $4 billion, $4 1/2 billion or maybe $5 billion at the outside. That is about half to two-thirds of the size of the tax cut that the Government gave in 1986-87-hardly `the biggest tax cuts in our history'. Even on that basis, people will get only about half of what the Government has taken through `bracket creep' alone in the last four years.

SPEECH.PARA: By any standard, or stretch of the imagination, it is a fairly miserable performance on the part of this Government when it comes to taxation. It has massively increased the size of the tax take, the range of new taxes and the complexity of the tax system, and it has got the Commissioner of Taxation out there banging on doors and chasing people in a way that is now causing enormous discontent; yet the Treasurer is walking into this place, around the country and overseas saying, `We are going to give fantastic tax cuts next year'-and we are all supposed to have a warm inner glow as a result. The fact is that people will get back only a small part of what the Government has already taken; indeed, in some cases it has taken it several times over. And they will have to pay for it by giving up their wage increases this year and beyond, and they will have to live with higher interest rates and higher home mortgage costs.

I am fascinated to see that the Treasurer is more concerned about his image and about the Australian Labor Party leadership. I suggest that he worries more about his electoral appeal than anything else. He worries, in particular, about his `recognition factor' in the polls and elsewhere. I can assure the Treasurer that while people in this country may have some doubt about what he looks like-and while they may have some uncertainty as to which particular brand of Italian suit he wears-they have absolutely no trouble identifying his hands, because it is his hands that have been in the pockets of every Australian.

Who can quibble about that? Who can quibble about trying to get to the people who have ripped off the system and made those at the lower end of the scheme pay? How terrible. Shock, horror. The Tax Commissioner and the Australian Taxation Office are cracking down on tax avoidance in big companies! Is that not dreadful? The honourable member says that the tax changes announced for next year and their magnitude are illusory. That is not the case. When this Government, unlike those opposite, makes announcements and put policies into practice, it can pay for them; the economy does not suffer.

I take honourable members back to the last election campaign in 1987. Who will ever forget the $8 billion worth of unfunded promises made by the Leader of the Opposition in his cynical grab for votes in that election? The Treasurer does not need to pass any tests. The Treasurer handed over the list of those promises that were made in that election campaign and challenged the Leader of the Opposition to put up or shut up, to show where those cuts could be made. Did he do so? No. Did he show how they could be funded? No, he did not. This whole question of cuts is very interesting. Once again, people such as the shadow finance spokesman and the Leader of the Opposition run around the country saying, `The Government must continue to cut expenditure'.

Let us look at that as an issue. I refer honourable members to the table on page 34 of the document Report on the Forward Estimates of Budget Outlays 1989-90 to 1991-92. That interesting little table shows the resultant cuts in programs necessary to achieve a one per cent decline in total government outlays if certain programs were excluded from funding. Firstly, if we excluded public debt interest and age pensions, a 1.2 per cent reduction in the remaining programs would be necessary, amounting to many hundreds of millions of dollars. What about public debt interest, defence and all personal benefit payments? Excluding the defence forces-the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) will be pleased about that-and taking public debt interest which has to be met and all personal benefit payments, the resultant decrease would have to be 2.1 per cent of all remaining programs, amounting to billions of dollars. Finally, if we excluded public debt interest, defence, all personal benefit payments and financial assistance grants to the States-in other words, if we do not knock off what the States get to fund education, health, police forces and so on-we would have to slash 3.3 per cent of the remaining outlays on other programs. Where would that come from? I am a little interested in this because there seems to be something of a contradiction in the comments made by the honourable member for Wentworth on this issue. In a speech on Australia's economic outlook that he gave to the 1988 Annual Conference of the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration at the Hyatt Hotel in Melbourne, he referred to illustrative figuring on tax cuts and said that he would have to look at cuts in government expenditure once again. He talked about the magnitude that would be necessary and said:
And about half of it could have to go on a ``Cass style Rolls Royce'' package for pensioners.
He was talking about where the tax cuts would be going. He said:
So watch the Government's rhetoric on tax cuts. Look, at most, for a small first instalment in July 89;
That is nonsense to start with. More importantly, later on the 7.30 Report, when he was questioned about necessary cuts in government expenditure he was asked:
If we have the sort of mega-cuts that you imply, doesn't that mean a recession for Australia that hurts the battlers?
The shadow spokesman for finance replied:
I'm not advocating mega-cuts. I was just saying that if you were to go into the expenditure side, that is one of the options.

What is he saying? Is he saying that we must cut expenditure, or what? The people of this country will suffer because of this nonsense. As I have demonstrated by referring to the Report on the Forward Estimates of Budget Outlays, clearly those sorts of cuts would have devastating effects on pensioners and those people who are caught up in the social security system who need our support-not just from those on this side of the House but right across the board. What would the Opposition do about them? How would it fund all these things? Quite clearly, it is a nonsense and simply an untruth to suggest that what the Treasurer and this Government have done has not assisted those on low incomes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) said, it is significant that whenever the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has an opportunity to come face to face with a reasoned argument on taxation and the economy, he darts out the back door and leaves it to the fourth graders. Today we have heard from one of the fourth graders-from one of the apologists. In 15 minutes the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) mentioned the family just twice.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are debating the declining standards resulting from the burden of taxation on the family unit. We should never forget that the endangered species under this Treasurer and under Labor are the productive sector, the taxpayer and the Australian family. There has been an attack on traditional and institutional values. We hear about tax avoidance and tax cheats. Tax is being avoided at the moment by some people who do not want to work and who do not want to have a family. I was told the other day of a couple being married in a church and their two-year-old daughter being the flower girl. When asked why they were taking this step now, they said, `It just so happens that we could not afford the deposit on a house unless the de facto, the mother, was able to draw a single parent's benefit'. In this way they were able to accumulate money and then afford to get married.

We should never forget that we are fast becoming a nation of people who will not work, who are not productive and who do not want to marry mainly because of the policies of the Treasurer and the Government. Many people are being sacrificed as a result of Labor's policies. I remind the honourable member for Macarthur that Labor had no policy on taxation or anything else when it came to office in 1983. All it had was an accord. Labor now has the hide to tell the Opposition that it has to have its policies in order so that it can criticise them. Within 12 months of the Treasurer's claiming that the 1987 policy on company tax could not be implemented he wholeheartedly adopted those rates, notwithstanding those comments.

Sacrifices have had to be made on Labor's high altar for excessive expenditure increases. I think expenditure has increased by 68 per cent since Labor has been in government. Taxation collections have increased by a record 74 per cent. There have been record Budget deficits of $25 billion in four years. There have also been record trade deficits. We should never forget that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) is a major ingredient of this Government. We should also take into account Labor's double standards. The family has been sacrificed and is being subjected to a growing burden of taxation.

I think it has been well noted that between the time Labor came to office and the end of 1988-89 there has been a decline of $56 per family unit in real levels of income. During that time, a 50 per cent increase in the consumer price index has been more than matched by the tax burden that has been imposed on families. An additional taxation burden has been placed on the family. I might just remind the Government that the dependent spouse rebate has not been indexed. This has meant a real drop in the rebate of some $610. The level of the family allowance has not shifted in that time and this, again, has resulted in a real decrease in living standards for its recipients.

Although the Government's business mates, the Bonds and everyone else, have flourished, the poor family itself does not rate a mention in the policies that Labor espouses. When I talk about the place of the ACTU in this Government, I need only remind the people of Australia of the Government's extravagant gesture to the ACTU about two or three years ago when, in order to get it to agree to the indexation guidelines, an ACTU delegation of six members was sent overseas at taxpayers' expense, at a cost of $86,000.

I always believed that a family was a group in which one spouse stayed at home to look after the children. Let us look at what has happened to these people under Labor. Such families exist on a single income. The Government has not allowed any income splitting for taxation purposes. This has meant that there has been not only a decline in living standards but also an increase in taxation for those people who want to do the right thing by the family and have someone at home to look after children so that they can be brought up to be proper Australians.

The spouse rebate has been pegged at $1,030. This is a real decrease of $610 in its value. This rebate has been available to de facto families as well as a de jure families. Twenty years ago the tax margin came into effect at a rate of 14 times average weekly earnings. Today it is payable at 1.19 times average weekly earnings. As a result, the family that the Government is supposed to be considering so well is being taxed almost at the marginal rate-as the honourable member for Wentworth said, at about 40c in the dollar. That is the sort of consideration that the Government is giving to families.

The 300 new tax initiatives and measures introduced by this Government mainly penalise the family and the taxpayer. The Medicare levy has resulted in an inferior service at a greater cost to the family man. Indirect taxation, which one might call a de facto consumption tax--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—If the honourable member wishes to interject, he might explain to us the reasons for the growing queues outside the general hospitals right throughout Australia. I think we are paying a very heavy price for the Medicare levy that is being imposed at the moment. The treatment given to the Treasurer in respect of the late lodgment of his taxation return was not given in an identical situation, to a family taxpayer in my home town who was called upon to pay $1,300.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that a fine?

Is the only family which can be a proper Australian family one in which one person works and one is at home? TALK.START.PARA: —Twice as much as they were five years ago.

—I do not need to hear from the Opposition. I just mention the gold tax because it is topical and recent. John Hyde is a former member of this House-he would have been on the other side-and someone whose views I might not agree with all the time but he is at least consistent. What does he say about honourable members opposite voting against the gold tax? He says:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Federal Liberals really believed in what they did, there would be much less reason to worry about them. It seems, however, that they opposed the gold tax to gain advantage in the coming Western Australian election, and to spite a leader they will not support but cannot replace.
Such pettiness and spite merely demonstrate their unfitness to govern.
This article is entitled `Tarnished gold tax vote shows Libs can't rule'. Honourable members opposite do not have any vision; they do not have any consistency.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the old mate over there?
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa should not be interjecting.

—Honourable members opposite do not have a philosophy. When we came to government we had to pick up the bits and pieces and make some sense out of them. If one looks at the business area, one sees that exactly the same occurred. There was a distortion of investment in business because of the tax system that the Opposition had set up. Again, marginal rates did not encourage profit; they encouraged speculation. This Government acted on that. It provided dividend imputation to remove the double tax on dividends. It provided the opportunity for businesses-small and large-to churn profits back into their businesses and to grow and become more productive. We have supported this. Again, I do not have to ask for support from this side of politics.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to Australian Business. In the 2 November edition John Gilmore-certainly not one who would be seen as a supporter of left wing views in the economy-under the heading, `It pains one to praise the World's Best Treasurer too much, but credit where credit is due', wrote:
Successive governments-particularly those tired Tories who have postured as supporters of free enterprise-
he was talking about honourable members opposite-
created a tax monster that penalised profit but encouraged speculation.
He went on further to say:
It pains this page-
he was talking about this column-
to give too much credit to the World's Best Treasurer. . . . But the Keating taxation reforms have won . . .

They have eliminated double taxation on company dividends, enabling small companies to plough profits back into their enterprises without penalty. They have ended the preference for speculation by placing capital profits on a similar footing to trading gains. They have indicated a sympathy for business by providing companies with the best tax rate available. They have created a climate for enterprise.

That is what we have done. That is what enables families to make money, to do better and in fact to have a reasonable tax system in which they can have confidence. Taxation is only part of the equation. In this debate we are also talking about how to manage the economy. People have to remember that we came here with a projected deficit of $9.6 billion. In five years we have turned it around to a surplus of $5.6 billion. We are talking about a massive turn around in how this Government spends its money.

If the housekeeper or the ordinary person in the street is thinking, `What do all these massive figures mean', they mean that one cannot spend more than one earns. With the opposition in government Australia was spending more than it earned. This Government has now turned it around. We are making a profit. Because we have been so successful in that, next year we will have substantial cuts in taxation as a result of good management of the economy. We have managed the economy by looking not only at the revenue but also at the outlays. As the honourable member for Macarthur suggested, we have cut outlays significantly three years in a row and in project five years. Even on the existing cuts five years of outlays decrease. That is a significant record and one which is important. This Government needs to be congratulated on it. When managing the economy it is a case of having a fiscal policy, a tax policy, a wages policy and a monetary policy which fit together and make some sense.

Honourable members opposite complain about interest rates. But if we say, `What are you going to do?' they do not have a solution. Of course, interest rates are rising as a result of overheated domestic demand. Some honourable members opposite are saying that there is too much demand on the domestic economy; others are saying that there is not enough. They are never happy. If they are to be consistent, they have to tell us how they would manage the economy. We are waiting for the Parramatta disclosure; we are waiting for the mandate for Liberal government from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

This matter of public importance refers to families and how they are affected. If we want to talk about families in this country let us look at what has happened. Per capita household disposable income, during the time of this Government, has risen every year except for one. The cumulative effect of five years of government has been an increase of 4.4 per cent in per capita household expenditure. We see an increase. In spite of the fact that there has been wage control and the necessity to tie down wages, household disposable income has increased.

The introduction of Medicare-it was mentioned by the honourable member for Dawson-is a significant social reform. It makes the position of families in this country safe. Do we want the same situation as that which exists in the United States where it is impossible for 20 per cent of the population to pay for its health costs? Last week the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) mentioned that the Opposition opposes every national wage case. If that were taken through to its logical conclusion, $132 would be lost by every taxpayer on average weekly earnings. They have opposed every national wage case in the last five years. On the one hand they are saying, `We have to spend more, do this and do that', and on the other hand they are complaining about us because we are trying to manage the economy fairly and in a reasonable way. Pensions are now at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. This Government has done the job.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, and by reason of the urgent nature of the works, it is expedient that the following proposed works be carried out without having been referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works: Infrastructure development at various federal airports.

The motion refers to the need of the Federal Airports Corporation to undertake infrastructure development in support of terminal developments being planned by Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines at various Federal airports. In October 1987 the Government announced that long term leases were to be negotiated with Ansett and Australian Airlines which would allow the airlines to develop future terminal facilities for domestic aviation operations. Under the terms of the leases signed in December 1987, both airlines are required to provide facilities for new air service operations after the two-airline policy ends in October 1990. This is an essential element of the Government's announced policies for the domestic aviation industry.

The Federal Airports Corporation is responsible for fulfilling the obligations of the lessor under these leases. In accordance with the timing required under the lease terms, Ansett and Australian Airlines were required to submit by 30 June 1988 indicative development plans for terminals and proposals for satisfying their obligation to provide access to new air service operators. Both airlines have met this timing. Ansett submitted detailed plans and indicated it needs to proceed immediately after 31 December 1988 in order to achieve completion by October 1990.

The Federal Airports Corporation had until the end of October 1988 to indicate its broad proposals for providing the additional infrastructure necessary to service the airlines' planned developments. It is also required to respond by 31 December 1988 with firm plans setting out the manner and timing of the infrastructure works. The work will include aprons, taxiways, engineering services, roads and parking. To varying degrees they will be required at Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth, Brisbane, Coolangatta, Hobart and Launceston airports. The latest estimate of cost by the Corporation for the various works is about $115m.

If, under the terms of the lease, the Federal Airports Corporation cannot provide a firm commitment and plans for the infrastructure works by December this year, the airlines could argue that they are being unreasonably delayed. The process associated with the public hearing and Public Works Committee consideration would almost certainly prevent the Federal Airports Corporation from meeting the December time frame and would also impact on a subsequent detailed planning, commitment and completion of works by the end of October 1990. Exemption is therefore warranted on the grounds of urgency. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning of construction can proceed with confidence. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It really is outrageous that the Government should come into this place on such an important matter and seek the House's agreement to it without providing any significant details or without referring the matter to the appropriate committee of this Parliament. The whole history of these terminal agreements has been irregular and the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) in his statement has highlighted the irregular nature of the matter. He said that in October 1987 the Government announced that long term leases would be negotiated. If my memory serves me correctly, in May 1987, some considerable time in advance of that, the Government announced it was going to establish the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), which would be responsible for running airports. We then have a reference to the terms of leases signed in December 1987, which was only a matter of days before the FAC was constituted, which was on 1 January 1988. The FAC is responsible for complying with its obligations under these leases which were entered into by the Department of Transport and Communications prior to its coming into existence.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister goes on in his statement to say that both airlines have met their obligations under the terms of this agreement. What he fails to say is that the Government has not met its obligations under the terms of this agreement. I think it would do the Government credit to provide more detail to the Parliament about what it actually proposes in terms of this structure. It is not as if it is not a controversial matter. We have had reports from people involved in the industry of their disquiet about the implications of this terminal expansion.

Whilst I would be the first to acknowledge the need to provide greater facilities at Australian airports as outlined in the statement, albeit ever so generally and without any detail, I think it is incumbent on me to say that there are many people, particularly those people who seek to enter the industry, who do not believe that the Government's intentions are in fact all that meets the eye. I would like the Minister to provide more details to the Opposition about the Government's intentions, rather than this rather bland and, I believe, inadequate statement.

It has been indicated by some people who seek to enter this industry that the terms of the lease agreements entered into with the two existing domestic carriers are such that they will be a major encumbrance to anyone who seeks to build his own terminal at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. We do not have any plans; we do not have any basis for examining what the Government has agreed to. We do not know what areas of land have been set aside for the existing concession holders. We do not know the terms of the leases. Although we have a freedom of information request in for those details, I am sure we will be told that it is a commercial undertaking.

We have a situation in which the Government has all the cards closely held to its chest and it is walking into this Parliament and saying, `Approve this expansion. Give us the right to spend $115m and trust us'. I would not trust this mob two inches. I really think that if the Government is fair dinkum about having a deregulated airline environment it should provide more information to the Australian Parliament and the Australian people. The whole issue, as I alluded to earlier, has been irregular from day one. The terms of the consultancy for the drawing up of the leases did not go to public tender. The leases were drawn up by the Department almost on the last few days of its authority over this area and we have yet to see any details of those leases and we have yet to see an adequate and comprehensive response from the Government to the criticism made of it by people who seek to enter the industry as a third and additional domestic airline.

I believe if the Government is to go any way to restoring its credibility in this area it should provide this detail, particularly in terms of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. I would like an assurance that there will be no restrictions placed upon the ability of a third airline to develop its own terminal at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and that there will be an option other than being a tenant of an existing airline operator. I realise that there are other members of the House who wish to speak on this motion, so I will curtail my remarks. I move:
That the debate be now adjourned.
I do so to allow the Government to prepare more information on these matters for presentation to the House.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Blunt's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of my colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications, (Mr Willis), I would like to take this opportunity to shed a little light on the issue for the benefit of the House. In formulating the comprehensive series of initiatives for deregulation of the aviation industry, the Government has recognised that the success of any such deregulation will be very much dependent on the ability of new operators to gain access to airport facilities which in the past have been tailored mainly to meet the requirements of the two airlines policy and the two airlines, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines.

SPEECH.PARA: The leases held up to the time of the renegotiation generally gave Ansett and Australian exclusive rights to their terminals until 1993, well beyond the start of deregulation in 1990. Following a basic assumption of common sense, the Government decided that in the absence of other available facilities it would be necessary to renegotiate the leases held by existing airlines to provide access to the terminals for other operators. The new leases were concluded with the airlines for the terminals at Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide, Hobart, Coolangatta and Launceston. The key conditions of the leases provide for a redevelopment and expansion of terminal facilities by the airlines to allow them to more effectively meet the public's needs, access for future entrants to the industry, and continued access for existing small carriers. The airlines are to pay greatly increased rentals and to accept responsibility for maintenance and operation of their entire terminal facilities, the cost of which was previously borne by the Government.

As a minimum, these leases set out what will be provided for new operators at the airport. I say `as a minimum' because it is by no means the full extent of what will be available for new entrants to the industry. From November 1990 operators will have access to gates within Australian and Ansett terminals at each airport where common use facilities are not available. As well as providing access to the new entrants, the leases recognise the commercial needs of existing airlines and require Ansett and Australian to undertake significant expenditure on future terminal developments, with the FAC providing complementary infrastructure. Australian and Ansett will each be required to make available two aircraft gates at Sydney and Melbourne and a gate each at Coolangatta, Adelaide and Perth. Launceston will have one gate in the Ansett terminal. The FAC has alternative facilities available at both Brisbane and Hobart. Under the terms of the leases the airlines have submitted redevelopment proposals to the FAC which commit the airlines to spending well over $300m redeveloping their terminals over the next two years. Additional development is planned for subsequent years. The proposed redevelopment will accommodate the growth of the industry. It will provide significantly improved terminal facilities for the travelling public and will assist the existing airlines and new entrants to cope with the demands of the deregulated environment into the 1990s.

The timetable on this issue is binding. In line with the Government's determination to ensure that access to terminal facilities will be available for new entrants immediately the industry is deregulated in November 1990, the leases contain a specific development timetable which is binding on the airlines and the FAC. I am advised by the Chairman of the FAC that to support the airlines' terminal developments it will be necessary to provide complementary infrastructure estimated to cost $114.7m. The majority of this amount of expenditure will be required at Sydney and Melbourne, the respective figures being $72.7m and $24m.

Expenditure at the remaining airports is estimated at $7.8m at Adelaide; $4.8m at Perth; $4.5m at Coolangatta; $700,000 at Hobart; and $100,000 at both Brisbane and Launceston. The first was why the FAC was not left to renegotiate these leases but rather the Government doing it before the FAC took up operations on 1 January this year. The answer is very simple. The negotiation quite properly was done before the FAC took up its reins. The second issue raised by the honourable member for Richmond related to the leases. Having gone through the very elongated process of deregulation of the aviation industry the Government is committed to making sure that the nuts and bolts of that deregulation fall into place. SPEECH.PARA: I find this a very valuable amendment to the original legislation of the National Crime Authority (NCA). It is an organisation that is not subject to any parliamentary review, and it has the most horrific powers of investigation and is almost uncontrollable now it has been created. On the other hand, we see the South Australian Government having a centralised body such as the National Crime Authority, which has been effective already in tackling areas involving corruption in South Australia, moving, in conjunction with the Inter-Governmental Committee, to strengthen the powers of the National Crime Authority to investigate within South Australia. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a pleasant prospect, speaking for the interests of one's own State, when one considers the special action that has to be taken as regards the scene in South Australia, the scene of the operations of the police force and the criminal element, such as the creation of another position on the National Crime Authority (NCA) in order to pursue the question in my own State. It must be said that, in relation to the number who may be corrupt, one is looking at a very small number indeed.

I guess the one good thing about this legislation is that at least it is being done with the full cooperative efforts of the Police Commissioner and the hierarchy of the police force in South Australia, the South Australian Government and the Inter-Governmental Committee, which have all agreed to take this move. If one wants the most effective revelations of crime in Australia, does one go to the police forces to find this out or does one go somewhere else, to the media or to a royal commission?

I remind the House that in Queensland the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct was brought about by Mr Phil Dickie's persistent pursuit in the Courier-Mail of crime, and by his personal devotion to combating crime wherever he found it. We know of a number of major instances in Australia where the lead has been given by dedicated operators within the media. These have been followed by royal commissions which have opened up scenes which none of us would ever have felt could exist in Australia.
