SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill. As I think has already been made clear by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), this Bill results from a request from the South Australian Government that the National Crime Authority Act be amended to enable the appointment of additional members to the National Crime Authority for the undertaking of specific investigations. We all understand that the South Australian Government has indicated that such an amendment will allow the appointment of an additional member of the Authority and that it will enable the Authority to investigate allegations of criminal activity and corruption in South Australia. Of course, the South Australian Government has agreed to fund that matter and has indicated that it is thought that the Authority is a more appropriate body to investigate those allegations in South Australia than a royal commission. I remind the House that the Minister for Veteran's Affairs (Mr Humphreys), who read the second reading speech on behalf of the Attorney-General, observed:

SPEECH.PARA: The Authority was established, in part, as a viable alternative to the then growing proliferation of Royal Commission-type inquiries . . . and in particular various aspects of organised criminal activity.
He went on to say:

The Authority's independence, coercive powers, knowledge and expertise in the fight against organised crime together with its focus on the gathering of admissible evidence make it the best alternative to deal with allegations of criminal activity and corruption of the kind being made in South Australia.

I am not a South Australian and I am not privy to all the allegations made in South Australia or to the breadth of those allegations-whether they relate more peculiarly to criminal-type activity or to a broader corruption of the type that we have recently become aware as being very prevalent in other parts of Australia. From the comments of the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), who spoke before me, we do know the nature of some of those allegations. Other than that, I do not come in here with a brief to make allegations about what has been happening in South Australia. However, from what I had heard of the Bill and from the Attorney-General's explanation of it, I did want to highlight the way in which the National Crime Authority itself says it works and my concern as to whether or not it is altogether the most appropriate body to investigate the sorts of allegations that are being made in South Australia on the basis observed by the Attorney-General.

I notice that in the report of the National Crime Authority for 1986-87 the Authority had some comments to make about the way in which it undertakes investigations. The report reminds us all of the following:
The National Crime Authority is empowered to investigate only that criminal activity which is considered `relevant' in terms of the enabling legislation.

I do not think that this enabling legislation takes the definition of `criminal activity' any further. It deals with the nature of the appointments to be made and the terms of reference that can be made within the legislation that we have already on the books. In relation to section 4 (1) of the National Crime Authority Act, the report states:

Section 4 (1) also defines `relevant offence' as meaning an offence which involves two or more offenders and substantial planning and organisation; the use of sophisticated methods and techniques; is of a kind of offence ordinarily committed in conjunction with other like offences and that involves theft, fraud, tax evasion, currency violations, illegal drug dealings, illegal gambling, obtaining financial benefit by vice engaged in by others, extortion, violence, bribery or corruption, bankruptcy and company violations, harbouring of criminals, passport forgery, armament dealings, or importation or exportation of fauna into or out of Australia.

It excludes certain matters specifically, such as offences committed in the course of industrial disputes; where the time for prosecution has expired; or where the punishment is less than imprisonment for three years.

The Authority in its report had some quite relevant comments of its own to make. One might have thought that a definition of `relevant offence' was wide and all-embracing, but clearly there is a range of matters of the sort that have come out in Queensland in the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct that will not be able to be raised in this investigation and certainly are unlikely to come to public knowledge by the way in which the National Crime Authority is charged with undertaking its own inquiries and investigations. The National Crime Authority has this to say:

A considerable number of people write to the Authority requesting it to investigate allegations of particular offences. More often than not these allegations fall outside the `relevant' offences which the authority is able to investigate and all the authority can do is refer the person on to the appropriate agency. In addition, frequently there are calls from the media and elsewhere for the Authority to investigate particular allegations. It must be stressed that the Authority is limited by its legislation, and of course its available resources, to investigating only those matters which fall within its charter. There is a tendency in some quarters to view the authority as an avenue for the investigation of all crime. This is a role which the authority simply cannot fulfil.

Mr Justice Stewart and his colleagues in writing about the way in which matters are referred to them for investigation make a point about its functions. As to the purpose of each of these investigations, they state:

(i) to ascertain whether any and what relevant offences, including-any offences suspected to be directly or indirectly connected with, or part of, a course of activity involving the commission of relevant offences have been or are being committed against laws of the Commonwealth or of a Territory or of the relevant State;
(ii) to identify the principal offenders;
(iii) to assemble evidence that would be admissible in the prosecution of offenders; and
(iv) to furnish that evidence to the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth or of the relevant State or to the relevant law enforcement agency for prosecution of those offenders.

So honourable members can see that we have an Authority which says that it is limited to investigating only those matters which are relevant offences. The definition of `relevant offences' is, of its very character, narrower than the range of matters that are often raised in relation to corruption per se. We have an Authority whose functions limit it to an investigatory role essentially in private where it assembles evidence and ultimately offers it to a body which has the responsibility for conducting a prosecution. On page 13 of the report the Authority states:

Criticism has been levelled at the Authority because of its reluctance to make public information concerning its current investigations. It should be stated that Authority officers are bound by the secrecy provisions contained in the National Crime Authority Act. The Act provides that it is an offence for a person to make a record of any information or divulge or communicate to any person any information acquired in the course of his or her duties under the Act.

The Attorney-General acknowledges that the Authority was established as an alternative method, but we need to understand that we have an Authority that has a very precise method of operation. I do not offer criticism of the Authority. I believe that it has undertaken its task with a great deal of enthusiasm. I believe, when I look at annual reports, that it is obtaining some success in referring matters to Attorneys and seeking to have prosecutions brought. I notice that the National Crime Authority's annual report records that, as a result of its investigations from its establishment to June 1987, 194 persons were charged with 540 offences and, in the financial year 1986-87, 143 persons were charged with 406 offences. So obviously it is having some success but, broadly speaking, in the area of corruption and the sorts of matters which have been raised in the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in Queensland, I do not believe that we have seen an inordinate amount of success from the Authority in alerting the Australian community as to what is happening. If we look at the nature of the Fitzgerald inquiry, those matters are much more prevalent than we would want to believe.

Whilst I have no personal knowledge of the matters that have been raised in South Australia and cannot add to those allegations in any way whatsoever, it seems to me that the National Crime Authority is not the body that is likely to bring about revelations of the sort that we have seen in Queensland. If one were concerned about the sorts of allegations that have been made in South Australia and whether they will be properly and fully investigated, one needs to have regard to the nature of the definition of what is a relevant offence. One needs to have regard to the extent to which the Authority has to fulfil specific functions and to its method of operation. If I were a South Australian concerned to know whether there had been extensive corruption of the kind that we have seen in Queensland, I would be concerned that this was the route that was being adopted.

I do not raise that matter because of any lack of confidence in Mr Justice Stewart or his colleagues. Rather, it is a concern that when such allegations are made they should be exposed clearly. They ought to be able to be seen and people ought to know whether their government is tainted in any way. I suspect that what we have before us is a form of investigation the information on which the South Australian Government intends should not be brought to light and should not be viewed clearly, in the public eye, and in the way in which the Queensland Government has been prepared to allow a proper investigation and exposure of all the allegations that have been made so that people can make a judgment about what is going on in their State. SPEECH.PARA: The National Crime Authority Amendment Bill really came about because, amongst other things, my colleague in the other place, South Australian Senator Robert Hill, has been actively crusading over many months for the establishment of a National Crime Authority (NCA) office in Adelaide to investigate allegations of widespread police corruption and evidence of the existence of organised crime in that State. Senator Hill is of the opinion that the corruption in South Australia, while very serious, takes the form of isolated pockets of criminal activity and corruption rather than being of an institutionalised nature. Obviously Senator Hill being from that State has a closer appreciation of the situation there than I do but I point out, as he has, that there has been a sequence of revelations leading to the establishment of the NCA unit which is very disturbing and justifies high level investigations of the calibre able to be offered by the NCA.

A former South Australian Attorney-General, now the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), has claimed that he first raised the question of police corruption in 1981. He of course suffered at that stage for so doing. In 1985 a former South Australian police officer broke a 13-year silence on the drowning in 1972 of a homosexual university lecturer, Dr George Duncan. As a result of his evidence, the case was reopened and two former vice squad detectives charged with Dr Duncan's death.

In the course of assisting the National Crime Authority in this case, other allegations were made in relation to other police officers, including several who were still serving and had reached high rank. The allegations suggested links between South Australian police officers and a major drug crop at Coffs Harbour and irregularity surrounding the shooting of a drug addict informer. Subsequently, a Crown witness, known as Mr X, had implicated the then Detective Chief Inspector Malcolm Moyse as a major police source for the supply of heroin, amphetamines, cannabis and cannabis resin. As we all know, Moyse was subsequently convicted in August of this year and sentenced to 27 years gaol with hard labour on 17 charges involving the sale, possession and supply of drugs. The senior position held by Moyse in the South Australian police force was serious in itself, but more so because he had also been responsible for the 1986 Operation Noah in South Australia and as such had appeared publicly on the media warning of the dangers of drugs.

There were other aspects of the Moyse case which were also of great seriousness, particularly the fact that he had obtained those drugs from the property section of police headquarters by falsifying disposal records. In effect, drugs were being apprehended and confiscated by the police and then being recycled back into the drug community through corrupt police for their own personal gain. In the course of the NCA's preliminary hearings into the Moyse case, revelations were made that the NCA had been given the name of six other senior policemen involved in drugs. It was alleged that a South Australian businessman was involved and that he had been able to blackmail at least one of these policemen into this position through the existence of video recordings taken of him in compromising positions at a brothel.

All these sorts of allegations made great grist for the media mill. But the Mr X tapes which are of great and serious concern indicated very serious levels of corruption through all levels of South Australian society-lawyers, policemen, businessmen, public servants and public service departments. There was also the allegation of possible political involvement. Given these sorts of allegations and the charges which had been laid and proved and convictions obtained, obviously there was a case for further investigation of many of the allegations and some additional ones. I am pleased that the Inter-Governmental Committee working together with the NCA has come up with the suggestion that this amendment that we are now debating be brought forward to the National Crime Authority Act to allow, from time to time under specific circumstances and with the unanimous, as I understand it, agreement of the Inter-Governmental Committee, for a person to be appointed for a specific reference. That seems to me to be a fairly cost effective way of dealing with the serious allegations of this nature. I note also that, because the request has come forward in the way that it has, the South Australian Government will be paying the costs associated with this operation and, therefore, it will not be an additional cost to the Australian taxpayer as such or the Federal coffers. However, we also will have a situation in which if, as a result of the reference, further allied investigations need to be made, the person who is appointed to this temporary position will be able to carry out those additional investigations if they can be demonstrated to be tied in with the original purpose for which the person was appointed. As the second reading speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) states:

The powers and functions of the additional member are limited to the original reference or any related references. The Bill provides that an additional member ceases to hold office upon the withdrawal of the original reference in relation to that member or the completion of the original reference or any related references.

I think that that is, on the face of it, a sensible way of dealing with what is obviously a very real problem in South Australia. We will be able to see the effectiveness of this method of dealing with allegations of this nature and of dealing with requests such as that made by the South Australian Government through the Inter-Governmental Committee.

Another aspect of the Bill which appeals to me is the fact that the person being appointed must be the unanimous choice of the Inter-Governmental Committee. I think that does away with any criticism that may have been made about special people being chosen for special jobs and being expected somehow to brush things under the carpet. I would not think for a moment that that would be the case, but I think the provision that it be a unanimous resolution or agreement of the Inter-Governmental Committee negates that potential criticism. In contrast to my colleague the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) I think it is a relevant way to deal with the problems being brought forward by South Australia. It is correct for the NCA to have charge of this investigation. It certainly is more correct for the NCA to do it rather than an internal investigation, which was originally suggested for dealing with the allegations that have been brought forward. I believe the NCA has established or is in the course of establishing a reputation for some independence of approach in these matters and I think that is a good thing. It has now gained some real degree of expertise in intelligence gathering which is not available to any other organisation of which I am aware. It has this expertise, as I say, and it also has the knowledge obtained from its dealings with the Moyse case.

So, in all those aspects of the situation, it is utterly proper that the amendment to the Act as put forward should be supported; but again it is in the nature, as is so much associated with the NCA, of an experiment. I would hope that the experiment succeeds because if it does we can have a way by which special investigations which may be required from time to time, coming from various States, can be dealt with in an expeditious manner without the development of a huge bureaucracy within the NCA.

For those reasons, I join my colleagues on this side of the House in agreeing with the proposition being put forward by the Government in relation to the amendment to the NCA Act. I might also say, as I mentioned to the Minister for Defence after his intervention in the debate, that it would not have been necessary for the Opposition to have taken that line of action if he, in his position as Leader of the House, had been more attuned to and aware of the needs of the people of Australia to believe that this House of the Parliament, the House of Representatives, is the proper place for discussions on matters such as were brought forward and are being brought forward by the Opposition. Attempts by the Government to choke off proper debate, to stifle any allegations which may or may not be made about members of the Government in the way that has been done, will only lead to further difficulties for the Government in getting its legislation through the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 10 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Government has always considered the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park to be one of the outstanding legacies of the Whitlam Labor Government, one which the Fraser and Queensland governments wisely built on and an issue, I hope, that will continue to receive bipartisan support. There have been notable achievements in the 13 years since the establishment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the commencement of work on the establishment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park:

The Great Barrier Reef region and all of the islands within it have been inscribed, with Queensland Government support, on the World Heritage List reflecting the importance Australians attach to this area;
The entire Great Barrier Reef Marine Park has been zoned with the zoning plan for the last section, the Mackay-Capricorn section, taking effect on 1 August 1988;
The establishment of a management approach which allows multiple use, while ensuring that the conservation values of the marine park are not devalued; and

Strong cooperative arrangements have been developed with Queensland to ensure a complementary approach to the management of Queensland lands and waters adjacent to the marine park and thus add to the protection of the reef.

The practical experience gained from managing the marine park during this period has highlighted the desirability of amending provisions of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act to ensure that these positive developments continue.

Honourable members will be well aware of the increasing level of commercial and non-commercial activity in the Great Barrier Reef. The number of visitors to the reef has been steadily increasing; it is one of Australia's main tourist destinations. There has been an expansion of commercial fisheries further offshore; an increase in recreational fishing; an increase in private boat use; an expansion of the number of tourist facilities, including resorts, pontoons and the world's first floating hotel. Tourism activities include diving, scenic cruises, helicopter and aircraft services and day trips to islands and coral cays. The relatively recent introduction of high speed catamarans, which can move several hundred people each trip, has opened up the more remote parts of the marine park to tourism. This growth has increased pressure, not only on the environmental quality of the marine park but also on the marine resources, scientific research and general use of the marine park. There is also a growing concern that this pressure, whether by accident or deliberate act or omission, will result in damage to the marine park. Therefore, given the scale of commercial activity and the limits to management resources, it is essential that there are incentives for users of the Great Barrier Reef to comply with marine park zoning plans.

It has been some time since the penalties applicable for breaches of the Act have been reviewed. With the increased level of activities in the marine park and the substantial profits to be gained, it is obvious that the existing penalties are inadequate to deter breaches of the Act. To rectify this situation it is necessary to transfer the main offence provisions from the regulations to the body of the Act. This transfer will allow the applicable penalties to be increased. The Bill provides generally for fines up to $10,000 for natural persons and $50,000 for corporations, although higher penalties apply in relation to some specific offences such as the discharge of waste, which incurs a penalty of up to $250,000 for corporations. This compares with penalties of up to $5,000 which apply currently in the regulations.

The Bill provides for the transfer to the principal Act of provisions dealing with offences in zoned and unzoned areas, contravention of conditions of permissions or authorities issued by the Authority in respect of entry into zones, contravention of directions issued by the Authority, the removal of property in the marine park, the discharge of waste in the marine park and the use of vessels and aircraft in the commission of offences. I am sure honourable members will agree that these offences can be serious as they could cause damage to this unique natural resource. Consequently, there should exist appropriate penalties. It should be noted that the transfer of penalties from the regulations to the Act will require a revision of the regulations. The transfer provisions and the associated increase in penalties therefore will not come into effect until these regulations have been revised and passed by the Parliament.

The policing of the marine park is a complex and time-consuming task. The Great Barrier Reef is an enormous area of over 350,000 square kilometres, which is an area larger than Victoria and Tasmania combined, and the resources necessary to supervise the use of the marine park must therefore be used effectively and efficiently. However, there is some concern, shared by the Government, that marine park inspectors presently have insufficient power to pursue, search and apprehend people suspected of committing offences against the Act. For example, an offender, once outside the boundaries of the marine park is not at present subject to the authority of inspectors. The Government believes that it is essential to the management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and its ultimate protection that inspectors have the necessary powers to enforce the Act. As a consequence the Bill provides for a number of amendments, including extending search and seizure powers to include aircraft and providing for the search of people, vessels and aircraft should offenders be apprehended outside the marine park. The Government recognises that the extension of police powers to marine park inspectors should be limited. The Bill therefore only extends these powers where a police officer is unavailable and only where there has been an uninterrupted pursuit of the offender from a place within the marine park to a place outside the marine park where the offender has been apprehended.

In addition, there have been circumstances in the past where an offence against the Act has resulted in damage or has posed a threat to the environment of the marine park. The Act, as it now stands, does not provide explicitly for remedial or preventative action to be taken nor can costs for any clean up be billed to the offender who caused the damage. As mentioned, the risk of environmental damage posed by increased use of the marine park has significantly changed since the Act's inception. There is, I believe, a need to deal with this risk effectively. The Bill therefore provides for the Commonwealth Minister responsible for the Act, provided there are reasonable grounds for believing an offence has been committed against the Act, to take such steps as are necessary to remedy actual damage or prevent possible damage to the marine park. Provision is also made for the Minister's powers to be delegated to the Authority or the Chairman of the Authority, subject to the directions of the Minister.

As an adjunct to the clean up or prevention of environmental damage provision, an amendment is proposed to allow the reasonable costs of the clean up to be recovered from the offender once a conviction has been obtained. The Bill also provides for the court, at the time of the conviction, to make orders concerning the payment of the debt, so as not to place the burden of another hearing on the judicial system. In meeting this objective of conserving the Great Barrier Reef it is essential that the Authority be given the full range of management tools to ensure the effective protection and management of the marine park while providing for reasonable use. One deficiency in the current Act is that obtaining a conviction does not necessarily deter future contraventions by the offender, nor does it undo the environmental damage resulting from the offence. While the Bill provides for remedial action to be taken, there may be circumstances where it would be preferable to prevent the occurrence or recurrence of the offence. The Bill therefore provides for the Supreme Court of a State or Territory to grant an injunction where there has been or is likely to be a contravention of the Act.

I should emphasise, Madam Speaker, that the court may grant the injunction on the application not only of the Authority but also on the application of a person whose interests have been or would be affected by the conduct in question. This new provision allows individuals to protect their interests while at the same time enforcing the provisions of the Act. This will facilitate a far more effective enforcement of the Act without incurring additional Commonwealth expense. The Authority's education expertise and its experience in natural resource management is recognised worldwide and is the subject of many requests for assistance.

Honourable members will recognise the valuable work the Authority has undertaken to inform and educate Australians, particularly users of the marine park, of its value and the need to use it wisely. Indeed, honourable members will be interested to hear that the Great Barrier Reef Aquarium, the Authority's major education and intepretive facility, has attracted over 320,000 visitors in the first year of operation and has won an award for the best Queensland tourist facility. The aquarium plays an important role in the Authority's education function and was funded with the assistance of the Commonwealth Government, as a bicentennial project, the Queensland Government, the private sector and the community of Townsville.

The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, recently had the opportunity of addressing the Sixth Coral Reef Symposium in Townsville, which was attended by 650 scientists and managers, the majority of whom were from overseas. The aim of the symposium was to promote global understanding of the growth and maintenance of coral reefs, which are important natural resources to many countries, particularly small developing island nations in the Pacific and Indian oceans. Often, many of these nations do not possess the scientific and managerial infrastructures to work by themselves to understand the complexities of coral reef ecosystems and to plan for the wise management of these important natural features. At this symposium the Government took much pride in the fact that Australia, through the Great Barrier Marine Park Authority, mainly as a result of support from the Federal Government, is in the vanguard of coral reef research and management throughout the world and has much to offer these smaller nations.

However, at present the Act does not permit the Authority to provide assistance to international organisations or individuals unless it directly concerns the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Australians should be proud of the reputation of the Authority and would, I am sure, want to share the Authority's expertise with other countries. As a consequence the Bill amends the Act by permitting the Authority to assist other institutions and individuals in environment management issues. To ensure that the assistance provided does not detract from the Authority's prime responsibility to manage the marine park, requests for assistance will be subject to ministerial approval. Provision is also made for the recovery of costs of providing such assistance.

The Bill also introduces a number of other measures to streamline and enhance the administration of the act. These relate to the disclosure of pecuniary interests of members of the Authority and the Great Barrier Reef Consultative Committee, application of the Audit Act 1901 to the financial, audit and reporting functions of the Authority, the jurisdiction of courts in respect to offences against the Act and the updating of the Act to reflect current drafting policy.

In conclusion, the Bill will be a significant step in assisting marine park managers to meet the new challenges that now exist while enhancing the protection of one of the world's greatest natural assets, the Great Barrier Reef, for the benefit of present and future generations of Australians.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend this Bill to the House.

The bundles float to the surface where they break up, and if they are lucky, the eggs are fertilised. The spawning event also aroused the interest of many of the Aquarium's fish who were observed feeding on the eggs.

The small larvae produced after fertilisation float and swim in the water for 4 to 7 days before seeking a place to settle. A special set of removable settlement plates have been added to the tank to record the number of types of corals that have completed their reproductive cycle and established a new colony in the tank.
The aquarium biologist, Dr Jan Morrissey, described the event as a `spectacular sight'. She said:
. . . we are delighted with the extent of the spawning.

She said she hoped that in the future it will be possible for the general public to view the mass spawning as a regular special event. Another matter to which I refer relates to the research work being undertaken by the Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS); that is, the plague outbreaks of the crown of thorns starfish. That was also mentioned by the honourable member for Gilmore who spoke previously. Those who read Hansard will be interested to know that the crown of thorns is a comparatively large multi-armed starfish which is found on coral reefs throughout the tropical regions of the Indian and Pacific oceans, including the Great Barrier Reef. It feeds on coral polyps but normally occurs in such small numbers that it does not seriously reduce live coral cover. It has been found in plague proportions on some reefs. In such cases live coral cover can be reduced significantly.

The first plague levels which occurred on the Great Barrier Reef were found in the early 1960s on reefs near Cairns. During the 1970s these early infestations declined, but some outer reefs and others further to the north and the south were affected. More recently, some reefs have been re-infested and, during the mid-1980s, it was claimed that plagues of starfish were again seriously damaging the reef. It was at that point in November 1985 that the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, with myself as Chairman, tabled a report entitled Protection of the Great Barrier Reef. The report dealt in part with the crown-of-thorns problem. The Committee found that the level of scientific uncertainty and arguments surrounding the issue meant that it was not possible to quantify the rest of the reef, but concluded that the level of probable risk was unacceptable. The main scientific arguments concerned the actual distribution of the starfish, the level of damage and whether or not the rapid but localised population increases were natural phenomena or were triggered by some man-made disturbance factor. The Committee recommended that additional funds be provided to implement a research program; that the crown-of-thorns starfish advisory committee be reconvened; that surveying and monitoring be extended; that priority be given to developing a research program for more efficient population control techniques; that zoning plans be modified, where necessary, to facilitate population control programs; and that a community-based response to population outbreaks be evaluated and, if practical, established. I am glad to say that the Government's response was generally favourable. Funding was provided for a research program and the advisory committee was re-established. The community-based control program was assessed and regulations were amended to allow mass collection of starfish in appropriate circumstances. I think that all members of the Committee were pleased that the Government made such a good response to our report.

Research reports have been produced. The latest findings on the crown-of-thorns starfish were discussed at a special session of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science entitled `Science and Life in the Tropics'. The research reports which were submitted at that session covered evidence of past outbreaks, effects of the starfish on long-lived corals, distribution of outbreaks, possible predators and biological control, as well as the effects on reef tourism. The lessons were clear. The crown-of-thorns starfish issue raises fundamental questions about coral reefs, one of the most complicated of all ecosystems, and requires a broad-based, long term program of research to find solutions for marine park management.

It is in that context that I take the opportunity of saying to the Government that I, and I am sure all members of my Committee, believe that it is absolutely imperative that the Government continue to provide research funding for this work. I note that in the issue of Reeflections to which I have referred that request is made. Also, in the copy of the latest publication issued by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority about the crown-of-thorns starfish it is said that some $800,000 per year for an intensive four to five-year coordinated research program on the starfish is presently being provided. That program is being conducted by the Australian Institute of Marine Science. Scientists from the James Cook University have discovered that the whole of the ecosystem on the Great Barrier Reef is extremely complicated and that it is absolutely essential to be able to understand how all the animals and the coral reef react one with the other. In that sense, it will be necessary to carry out the research for a longer period than was envisaged originally.

At this stage it is thought that there is not just one reason for the crown-of-thorns starfish plague but many reasons. In fact, it could very well be that the influence of human beings on the Great Barrier Reef is one of the causes, but there could be others. I understand that evidence has been produced which shows that in the past there have been crown-of-thorns plagues. When I say `in the past' I mean some thousands of years ago. So it could be an actual phenomenon but the only problem could be that because of human influence those outbreaks are occurring perhaps more rapidly than before. Obviously in such cases there are differences of opinion among scientists about the problem of the crown-of-thorns starfish. Perhaps the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has not given the same significance to the outbreaks that have occurred on the reef, as have some of the scientists from the Australian Institute of Marine Science. That was clear from a program on The World Today on Australian Broadcasting Radio on 14 November 1988. Dr Bradbury of AIMS was interviewed on that occasion and it was clear that there is some difference of opinion. As I understand it, he believes that these outbreaks are perhaps more significant than the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has indicated so far.

There is a lot more work to be done in this area. I ask the Government to ensure that funding is made available for this work. I have spoken a number of times in this House about the fact that the Government has reduced research funding to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, universities and the Australian Institute of Marine Science. Again, I stress that I believe that that approach is shortsighted. I think that we should restore this funding to all those bodies. One of the most perfect examples is the crown-of-thorns starfish and other problems on the reef. The reef is a great money spinner for Australia. Tourists flock there in their hundreds of thousands. It is a natural environmental area of great beauty and great wonder and it is something which we should continue to protect.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess the problem when one is concerned with ecology and the environment is that people race to put banners on other people. One is either a greenie or one is not a greenie; one is an environmentalist or one is a developer.

TALK.START.PARA: —You look pretty green to me.

—I am pleased to hear the Minister at the table, the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), whom I count as a friend, say that I look pretty green to him. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite a pleasure to be able to stand in a debate in which the previous speaker has said that the Opposition totally agrees with the Government. I thank him for his frank and warm support for this measure.
—Such a rare event.

—It is a rare occurrence, but a delight nonetheless. This measure has a number of points which deserve some mention in this debate but I shall pause to cover only a couple. Firstly, there is a very substantial increase in penalties. Penalities have been increased from a maximum penalty of $5,000 to penalties of $250,000. They reflect the reality that environmental damage, oil spills, degradation and acts of vandalism against the reef could incur such significant costs to the environment that penalties in the order of $5,000 are simply not sufficient to deter that kind of conduct. Given the fact that the Great Barrier Reef is part of Australia's natural heritage, part of its treasure and part of its environment, appropriate penalties up to $250,000 are a very sound and sensible response.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Bill provides that where environmental damage is caused, there is possibility of civil recovery so that the cost of clean-up can be recovered against those responsible for that environmental damage. That is something, I believe, that we should build increasingly into all our legislative measures in the field of environmental control. It is something that this Bill recognises and builds in. It means that the public will not be left to carry the cost of necessary environmental clean-ups but that the offender who has been identified as being responsible can be brought to account for the costs that his or her actions have incurred.

Finally, a point that is worth mentioning-I understand it has not been covered in debate previously-is that the Bill allows the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to extend its work and expertise internationally. It has become one of the leading authorities on coral reef environments and there are many countries which cannot afford institutions such as this which would benefit from the Authority's learning and experience. I note, for example, just to the north of Australia, Papua New Guinea has very substantial and most beautiful reef structures which may in time come under some of the same kinds of threats that the Great Barrier Reef is subject to. The capacity for the Authority to make its expertise available to Papua New Guinea and other such nations will be of value to those countries in the future.

There are important measures in this Bill which go towards improving the regime of environmental protection that the Government and the previous Government have extended towards the Great Barrier Reef because this is landmark legislation. Today we take it for granted that the Australian nation will preserve environmental monuments such as the Great Barrier Reef and protect them for future generations of Australians. That comfortable certainty that we have now is a relatively new phenomenon. Only 10 or 15 years ago the idea that the Australian nation could intervene to protect these from desecration was a new and somewhat troubling idea for many in this Parliament. I understand it still troubles the occasional backward looking member of the Opposition from time to time, raising spectres of States rights and central control.

However, at least on some of the fundamentals we have now reached the position where there is bipartisan support for protection of at least the most significant parts of Australia. As I say, that is a relatively new phenomenon and an important one. It is my responsibility, responding to the warmth and kindness of the Opposition in this debate, to say that the Australian nation owes a considerable amount of respect to the work of the previous Fraser Government in the field of environmental protection because, of course, it was the Fraser Government which carried through the landmark, epoch-making moves of the Whitlam Government to protect and to maintain protection for significant areas of Australia's environment. That record has been picked up, carried on and expanded by the Hawke Government.

A recognition that the Australian nation has a responsibility to protect sites of great national significance in Australia has been a growing one. Of course, I come from Tasmania, where I guess we have been at the cutting edge of a number of debates and arguments about the extent of the national Government's responsibilities to protect the natural environment of Australia. The Government made courageous decisions on the Gordon River. It prohibited developments which would have destroyed that most beautiful river system for the sake of a power development that the Tasmanian Government's own advisory body, the Hydro-Electric Commission, now says was unnecessary, not required, and surplus to industry needs.

The national Government also has taken a strong position in relation to the protection of the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests. That was a controversial decision but, nonetheless, the Australian Government took a tough, correct, hard decision. It has done so recognising its responsibilities to protect both jobs and the environment. The national Government has ensured that measures are put in place so that the economic interests of the State of Tasmania and those dependent on the forest industries are protected and looked after while at the same time its responsibility for protecting the environment is given proper weight.

The background for the debate today is, I suppose, of interest given the decision of the Helsham Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests in Tasmania. When the question of protection of the Great Barrier Reef first arose the Government commissioned a group of experts to advise it. That group, by a majority decision, recommended the possibility of oil exploration and exploitation of resources under the Great Barrier Reef. Looking back, I think we can say-this is a view shared by both sides of the Parliament, made obvious by the debate today-that nobody in this House would wish such an attack on the fundamental wilderness values of the Great Barrier Reef to proceed. However, we can be comfortable with that view only in hindsight. At the time there was a considerable and lively opinion, particularly expressed by the State of Queensland, that oil exploration on the Great Barrier Reef must proceed. It took a considerable act of political courage for the national Government to stand by its guns and protect that reef in the national interest.

The same situation has applied in regard to the response to the Helsham Inquiry. The national Government was confronted by a majority report which recommended that a significant portion of the Southern and Lemonthyme Forests be made available to the timber-getting industry. The Government was faced with some difficult conundrums and decisions in reconciling its twin commitments to the environment and the protection of jobs and industry. I place on record my own view that the Government has made a very sound and well-balanced decision-in the end rejecting the majority recommendations of the Helsham inquiry but proceeding, appropriately, to protect those who depend on forest resources for their living. At the same time it has ensued that the vast wilderness areas of particular heritage value in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests are protected. I note that today there are ongoing discussions between the Tasmanian Government and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to that matter. I have not yet been advised of the outcome of those deliberations and discussions, but the framework for making sure that both jobs and the environment are adequately protected has been established by this Government. That is something that I believe we on this side of the House have reason to be proud of.

Our attitude towards attacks on and degradation of the environment is slowly changing. It was the case that many years ago we assumed that our environment was boundless; that it could suffer almost endless damage without suffering irreversible harm. Tasmania is an instance of some of the legacies of those earlier views coming back today to haunt us. For example, the Derwent River is suffering from years of neglect. It is a very sad experience for me to go along the foreshore of the river at Claremont, where I grew up as a young boy, and see the sludge that has been washed along that foreshore. The sludge is about 18 inches to two feet thick. It has a very strong and unpleasant smell and has a tarry, thick, treacly texture. I am told that it consists of various sediments mixed with wood products. It is believed to be the residue of materials discharged into the river from a papermaking factory. I understand the theory is that that material stayed on the bottom of the river for a number of years-some 20 or 30 years-but has now, over the course of time, with the action of chemicals, waves and various other forces, broken loose. Great scabs of this sludge-like material have come downstream and lined the river banks.

What I am saying is not being said in order to cast aspersions on the particular industry that was involved; although, of course, in hindsight, it is appropriate to say that the environmental controls that permitted those kinds of discharges and build-ups obviously were not adequate. My comments are more a reflection on the fact that in earlier days we really believed we could continue to treat rivers as open sewers and that they would absorb all the materials that we could throw at them. We believed that because the rivers discharged out into the seas there would be no significant environmental build-up. We look around us now and see that those judgments have been proved to be incorrect. It is a particular sadness of mine, having grown up in Claremont and remembering those river banks where as a young boy on hot summer days I used to dive into the river and swim, to know that the State Government now suggests that it is not safe to swim and urges people not to eat the trout they catch in the river and certainly not the shellfish that can sometimes still be found. The Derwent is one of Australia's largest and most beautiful river systems. For it now to be in such a condition I think reflects the kind of re-evaluations we have to make in terms of our responsibility to the environment.

Of course, it is not just the River Derwent that is affected. In northern Tasmania there are real concerns about the factories that were built along the coastline and discharge directly into Bass Strait. In southern Tasmania there are real concerns not only about the paper factory, which obviously has some difficulties in terms of its discharge, but also other industries which discharge their effluent directly into the Derwent. In Tasmania we have a number of steps to take in order to protect our environment. It is not surprising that in Tasmania we give this issue very considerable priority. I believe we are the gem of Australia. None surpasses Tasmania in beauty; in such a small compass it contains some of the most beautiful scenery, most rugged countryside and most delightful old buildings that any State could possibly contain. We have a great understanding of the need to get away from a reckless approach to our environment and to look instead at planning so that we can develop our State within sustainable and long term achievable economic constraints. We cannot continue to hack and chop and dig without any concern for the future.

That brings us back to the content of this Bill. Australian governments both Labor and Liberal have said of a number of important Australian natural heritage areas that they are the responsibility of all Australians. The Great Barrier Reef was one of the first areas-I believe it was the first-where that kind of attitude was taken by the national government. It is pleasing that not only was this landmark legislation but that the legislation continues to have the support of both sides of the House and continues to be improved to make sure that the Great Barrier Reef, which is one of the great natural wonders of the known world, is protected for all generations into the future. Those who follow us into this Parliament over the next 40 to 100 years will look back on the 1970s and 1980s and will see the steps we took to protect the natural environment-faltering at first, more confidently as we moved on into this decade-as moves which justified our role as national parliamentarians.

If federalism means anything, it means that sometimes the interests of those at State level have to be subordinated to the interests of all Australians. It is not simply a question of States' rights. It is a question of recognising that some parts of our environment and our heritage are so important that they require the protection and the intervention of the national Parliament. That recognition has slowly come and is now broadly accepted on both sides of this House. Those are important developments of which we, as members of the Australian Parliament, have a right to be proud.

We also have another responsibility towards those who look to work, who look towards an economic future, who look towards the right to develop their skills and potentialities within the Australian society. Our attitude cannot be-I believe that is true of both sides of this House-an attitude simply of protection and preservation without regard to the interests of workers, those affected by the decisions we make. It is always important to make sure that the balance is right, that we maintain the interests of those who look to us to protect their jobs and to make sure that they have an economic future. It is crucial to get that mix right, to protect both jobs and the environment, to make sure that those who work have a right to look forward to our continued interest in their welfare and future. Those are difficult decisions sometimes and difficult balances to make but it is crucial to Australia's future that we continue to get that balance right, and particularly in relation to this Bill it is pleasing to see that both sides of the House are as one on the balance to be struck in this instance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are witnessing, as all speakers on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill have said, a measure that is supported by both sides of the House. The honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) made a very strong point of this and during a bit of banter made the comment that there would be a lot more bipartisan support if the Government were to bring in lots of sensible legislation as it has done tonight. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) mentioned the Daintree and the wonders of that area of Australia, in north Queensland; a beautiful part of our country that must be protected at all costs, like the reef we are talking about tonight. He mentioned that some of the actions by the Queensland Government in allowing certain things to take place, were leading to damage being done to the reef from run-off from a road constructed through the forest. In actual fact there is no evidence to suggest the reef is being damaged.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) made some very good points and he too highlighted the fact that it is very good to have bipartisan support for this Bill. He talked about his State of Tasmania which is also fiercely spoken about in a protective way by all honourable members from Tasmania, not the least being the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) who is here tonight and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck). We know his views on Tasmania and the views of the former honourable member for Denison who fiercely fought for that great State which he represented for so long. The present honourable member for Denison commented that it was very good to see these regulations coming in, as strong as they are. He talked about the forests in Tasmania. It gives me an opportunity to compliment the Tasmanian Government because that Government is one of the only State governments, if not the only State government to imbed in legislation the forest preservation protocol, the rules and regulations with regard to how forests are to be treated, restored and so on. There are not too many States, if any others, where that has been done.

Tonight I have much pleasure in taking part in the debate, as deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, which has a very special interest in this Bill. I know you Mr Deputy Speaker, not so long ago were also a member of that committee and took a great interest in the preservation of our environment. As I have said before, earlier speakers on the Bill have already outlined the details of the amendments, which are proposed to improve the protection and management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. It is one of the greatest environmental wonders of this whole earth, not just Australia, for which the people of Australia have a very profound responsibility. Three of the proposed amendments have to do with deterring and sanctioning irresponsible action which harms the fragile environment of the reef. Penalties are to be increased.
