I mention these three areas of amendment not just because I support them but-it may seem odd to say it-because I do so with deep regret. It is to our great shame that there are still some members in our community who need to be deterred from damaging such wonderful areas as the Great Barrier Reef. Some of the pressures facing the reef's environment have to do with the volume of tourists and recreational activity within the park today which is ever on the increase, it seems. These amendments, however, remind us of the awful truth that there are people with no sense of responsibility concerning the environment. They are determined to damage fragile areas of the environment in pursuit of personal gain. It is almost impossible to believe but the sad fact is that those people do not seem to care. Perhaps these new amendments to discourage such activity will be effective. They remind us that our environmental responsibilities include resorting to force and punishment where necessary to protect those areas or those animals which face destruction.

I make those comments because there are some in the community who are critical of the powers being assumed by government in the area of environmental protection. The fact that we have to legislate to protect what is without doubt an area of unique and crucial environmental value to the world simply reveals that the development of such powers by the Government, on behalf of the majority of citizens, is in response and in proportion to the irresponsibility of a minority of citizens. It is simply another case where, in Edmund Burke's words, `their passions forge their fetters'. This means that an extension of governmental power occurs when a few irresponsible people provoke a collective response to restrain and sanction their actions. It would be a great thing if such necessities were not needed in this society in which we live but, unfortunately, they are.

Having indicated my support for this Bill, and having commented on why the Government's proposals are necessary and appropriate, I want to make some comment on the way the positive aspects of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park highlight the negative and counterproductive approach of the Government concerning newer areas proposed for World Heritage listing. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), when introducing this Bill in the Senate, identified as notable achievements that the marine park had been inscribed in the World Heritage List with the support of the Queensland Government and that strong cooperative arrangements had been developed with Queensland to ensure a complementary approach to management of adjacent lands and waters. The keys to the park's success and to its listing on the World Heritage List were a complementary approach to management responsibilities and the support of the State Government. To identify these two factors is to beg the question: Why has the Government rejected these two factors in its approach to proposals for World Heritage listing which have been developed since it assumed office?

One of the other notable achievements identified by the Minister was the establishment of a management plan which allows multiple use while ensuring that the reef's conservation values are not devalued. Once again this begs the question: If multiple use is so compatible with the reef's conservation within the management plan, why can it not be an objective of management plans being proposed by the Government for other prospective World Heritage listings? State support, complementary management responsibilities and multiple use of the environmental asset are the three keys to the success of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and the very three factors missing, it seems, from the Government's approach to negotiations with the States on proposals for World Heritage listings in 1988.

Without doubt the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park needed to be listed as a World Heritage area. I do not think anyone would argue with that. Without doubt we need constantly to review the legislative tools at our disposal to ensure that our powers to protect the reef are effective. I therefore support this Bill and commend the Government for bringing it before the House. I simply ask the Government to look at the success of the park and its management and to realise that were it to change its confrontationist and centralist approach on World Heritage matters there could be success stories similar to the reef throughout Australia in the years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly on the remarks of the last speaker, the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), in relation to World Heritage listing and the fact that some of the States may agree to this proposal and there should not be a confrontationist attitude. One has only to look at what has happened in the past in relation to Tasmania, Queensland and the Northern Territory. Wherever the Federal Government has put up anything that affects, so the States believe, their rights and their control over that particular area, they have opposed it, especially those States led by Liberal or National Party governments. I think it is important that we as a Commonwealth government take in the interests of all the people of Australia, not just the interests of the people in a particular State. I am firmly of the belief that the environment is definitely an issue for all Australians, not just the people of Tasmania or Queensland, or even the people of New South Wales, where I believe the Greiner Government is looking closely at changing a few things.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that many world leaders have come around to putting the issue of the environment in a position of importance. I remember that only 15-odd years ago the environment was not on the agenda of any Australian political party. It has come from nowhere to be in the top five or six issues in any political campaign. This is great. I believe it should be right on the top; however, I am little biased, being a conservationist. To be in the top group is very important. I am quite certain that children, the future voters, will thank this Government for the actions it has taken in proclaiming World Heritage areas and looking after them, especially in relation to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. I have been fortunate enough to have been there on two or three occasions. I can assure all those people who have not been there that it is worth while visiting.

I was interested in an article in the Australian Financial Review in October of this year in which the subject of conservation was found to have reached some very conservative parties throughout the world. There have been some very conspicuous converts, including President-elect Bush. He has pledged his allegiance to clean water. Perhaps more surprisingly, Mrs Thatcher, previously happy presiding over one of the least controlled industrial climates in Europe, has also spoken strongly on the need for accelerated environmental concern. Maybe this comes about from the pressure of countries in Europe telling her that they do not want the dirty air from England's coal-fired power stations. They do not want to be at risk from the United Kingdom as one of the polluters of the North Sea. World leaders who have been very conservative on this matter and who have not worried about it in the past are beginning to take note. They are beginning to recognise that the world is a finite planet-it is not infinite-and we are doing a lot to destroy it. However, we can take remedial steps. I urge people who read this speech or who are involved in conservation to play their little part in making certain that our environment is looked after.

The green or environmental movement has raised real concerns to governments. It has put the issue to the forefront, which has not been the case in the past. There are a few on the fringes of that movement who have ratbag ideas, but on the whole the majority of the environmental movement is very responsible. What they are concerned about is real and it is here now. They know that it will affect the future. We have to make certain that the quality of life of all those here is put before some of the resource projects that are mooted around the place and the quality of life for our future generations is looked after.
It is very interesting to note that just recently the coalition's environment policy was released. One of the areas that they have put forward for change is in relation to the World Heritage List:
The World Heritage Listings could be freed by a coalition government for other uses, the Opposition's environment spokesman Senator Puplick, said yesterday.

He said a coalition government would not withdraw from the World Heritage Convention, but it would examine areas listed without the consent of State governments to see what other land uses, now prohibited by the Federal Government's World Heritage legislation, could be allowed. This raises the prospect of allowing the timber and cattle industries into the North Queensland `wet tropics' rainforests. At present these are protected by an interim World Heritage nomination.

It could also allow some sort of mining on the Great Barrier Reef. It could allow some removal of the forests in relation to Tasmania. It could allow more mining in Kakadu. These are the real things we have fought for, that the environmental movement have stressed are important; but already the coalition has said that they may change these things. They are being very cagey in all their policies. They are not saying they will do it, but that they may. They are attempting to balance off those in their party who want open slather on resources and those other people who vote and think about the environment.

There was an article in a magazine called News Weekly, which I do not often read but happened to read on this occasion because of the headline. It makes some interesting comments. It says: `Federal Liberals: the born-again ``greenies''.' This is amazing. The article reads:

The political wisdom of the flagship of the Fairfax media interests, the Sydney Morning Herald, is approximately equal to the financial wisdom its owners displayed in buying Melbourne's Channel 7, and then disposing of it at a loss of some $150 million. In other words, the level is not high.

It praised Mr Howard for his post-election discovery that the Liberals have to come to terms with the environmentalists, because it no longer does them much good in terms of votes to claim that powers over legislation affecting the environment should be left with the states. Mr Howard regrettably advanced no principle to justify this change of position, since there is no principle which makes a bunch of federal Cabinet Ministers and federal civil servants located in Canberra more likely to make correct decisions in relation to any particular environmental question than a bunch of State Cabinet Ministers and State public servants in any State capital. Mr Howard's conversion is, therefore, not related to principle. It is relate solely to the fact that, in the recent federal election, the ALP successfully concentrated on the `yuppies' . . .
And it goes on to denigrate certain people and certain papers.

It is true that the environmentalists, the green movement, the protection of the forests people and the Wilderness Society came out and worked hard in the last Federal election. I must say that my electorate, the most marginal Federal Labor seat in Victoria, was helped considerably by the work of the members of Wilderness Society. They did a good job and worked extremely hard for their cause, and their assistance helped me to win the seat. I think that Peter Coaldrake, of Queensland University, even acknowledged that. It is pretty unusual for a statistician in political analysis to recognise that they did play a part in the last Federal election. I am very proud to be associated with them, because what they have done and what they continue to do is make certain that the environment is high on the list of priorities of the Australian Labor Party, in particular, and all other parties.

In relation to the Great Barrier Reef, there has recently been concern in respect of the floating hotel, which is I think still owned by Barrier Reef Holdings. It is up for sale. I have raised in this House, even when the Sea Installations Act was being discussed, my concerns about what would happen if it sank and who would remove the remains lying on the seabed. We have got a good example of that concern at that moment. A recent press release stated:

A $1 million man-made island on the Great Barrier Reef off Townsville broke in half and sank. Fantasy Island, moored just 800 metres from the Four Seasons floating hotel, broke up in heavy seas about 11.30 p.m. on Monday night and finally went under about 4 p.m.

This was some months ago. From what I can tell, Fantasy Island is still sitting on the bottom. No one knows when it is going to be removed. Whose responsibility is it to remove it? It is probably the owner's responsibility, a Mr Tarca, who actually took it out there. But when will he remove it? No-one really knows. It has been sitting there for some time. I believe there are discussions going on between the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and himself. But what would happen if something did go wrong with this huge hotel that is sitting on a magnificent piece of the reef called John Brewer Reef?

I imagine that these questions will be resolved in the courts in the future. Perhaps Doug Anthony, who is one of the directors of Barrier Reef Holdings, will move in fairly rapidly and see whether he can fix it up. I know that he was involved during the construction of this hotel in Singapore when it was not to be released from the shipyard due to the work force claiming that they had not been paid enough. I believe that he was involved in negotiations in getting things moving there. I also believe that, as a director, he was involved in the sale of this particular floating hotel.

There are many more proposals to build floating hotels. There is a proposal to build one on the Barrier Reef. I believe there is a proposal to build a hotel and tow it down to a bay in Antarctica. This is a novel approach. It appears as if, at present, people have not flocked to them in the numbers that one would have expected. It appears that the management of the floating hotel on the John Brewer Reef has abided by all the conditions. I notice that one of the amendments was in relation to waste. I believe that it has been responsible in protecting the reef. However, I can only ask again: What happens if something goes wrong? What happens if it does sink and vanishes beneath the waves, as Fantasy Island did? Who will clean up the mess? Who will pay for it? I believe that one of the conditions that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority puts onto floating hotels is a bond in relation to cleaning up any damage. Is this enough? These are the questions one should be looking at in the light of the Fantasy Island experience.

There are also many other plans for developments on and around the Great Barrier Reef. One of the them is for a resort that is planned near Fraser Island National Park. It is in the same area, a little to the south. It is a $700m tourist resort on the Sunshine Coast. It will go ahead within the next few months-pending the review by Mr Ahern. The press report I have goes back to July, so I am not certain what has happened there, but there are many of these types of proposals that have been put forward which will put a lot of pressure onto the Great Barrier Reef. It will also put a lot of pressure onto the staff and management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Perhaps the Authority should be looking at upgrading the people working for it and some of its regulations in the light of what has happened with Fantasy Island. All these things-the pressure of tourism, et cetera-are making it harder for developers not to press ahead with new and exciting ideas for the Great Barrier Reef. We should be aware of what could go wrong all the time, but let us hope that nothing does go wrong.

The amendments that are being put into the legislation this evening will assist in making certain that the Government can rectify some of the problems before they happen. They are good amendments. In the light of what has happened in the past we should look at these amendments all the time and keep the legislation up to date. The Great Barrier Reef is a wonder of the world. We must at all costs protect it. We must not permit the Liberal and National parties to change the World Heritage policy to allow some other activities within these areas. We must not allow them to go ahead with drilling, as Sir Joh wanted to do some time ago. We must not allow them to change the actual conditions and permit mining and logging to go ahead in our national park. These areas are put aside for everyone, not just for the people of those States. Australia is a very rich country. We can afford to put these areas aside. We do not really need to log or mine them. What we are doing is looking up--

TALK.START.PARA: —When was the last time you logged the Great Barrier Reef?
—We are locking away these particular areas for future generations, and that is good.
—But you don't log them.

—The honourable member says that we do not log the Barrier Reef. He is quite correct, but one of the leaders of his Party wanted to mine it and drill right through it. Let us have a look at these things. That is wrong. That was something that the National Party wanted to do. The National Party had a leader called Johannes Bjelke-Petersen who was a heavyweight of the Party. He wanted to make certain that poles were put right through the middle of it. Just imagine what would happen if oil were found there and there was an oil spill. So what? I get no answer from members of the National Party. They are not particularly concerned at what would happen, but I assure honourable members that it would be devastating to all life on the Great Barrier Reef. We do not need that oil and we do not need to know what is underneath. Maybe another 100 years in the future there will be technology that can drill on an angle from 50 miles out and it will be okay to get the oil, if there is anything underneath. But at present we do not know how to handle it and I think the wisest thing to do is what this Government is doing; that is, making certain that nothing happens in those particular areas.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments go towards determining that nothing will happen to these excellent places within the world. I am quite certain that many other areas in Australia could be listed as World Heritage areas. I hope those areas will be explored by the Government and nominated in the future. We have to get them now before some changes to the State governments come about. Maybe in another 10 years there might be a change in the Federal Government and it will allow these sorts of things to go ahead. That is why we have to do these things now and make certain that these areas are saved, not just for the people of those States, but for the whole of Australia and the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed with some of the comments just made by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth). We have chaired committees together, as you and I have, Mr Deputy Speaker, and have taken an interest in the Great Barrier Reef. I am disappointed that the honourable member for Dunkley made a partisan comment during his contribution. He intimated that in some way the Liberal and National parties would desecrate the Great Barrier Reef in violation of the natural heritage of that area. I remind the honourable member for Dunkley that the Liberal and National parties during the Fraser Government period established the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. The Fraser Government put in place those things that would give greater protection to the Great Barrier Reef. The Fraser Government in its single-minded determination decided that the Great Barrier Reef would never be violated by unnecessary development that was not in keeping with the protection of the unique natural heritage of that area.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the honourable member that in no way would any future Liberal-National Party government ever violate the natural heritage of that area because we believe that it is one of the world's unique natural heritage areas and that it should be protected for future generations of mankind. For the honourable member to suggest that in some way an incoming Liberal-National Party government would have, as part of its policy, the violation of that great unique natural heritage is to give a completely false impression to the people of Australia. That is not part of our policy and I assure the honourable member that it never will be.

I remind the honourable member that a unique feature of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill is that it has bipartisan support from all parts of the House. I hope that the debate can continue on a basis that this Bill and the provisions of this Bill are supported by all parts of the House. All of us in this place-and I think all the people of Australia-believe that the Great Barrier Reef is one of the world's unique natural areas. We, as Australian citizens, have a responsibility to protect that area, not just for future generations of Australians, but for the world. It is unique. I believe that all of us, regardless of which party may be in government, will do that. The Bill before the House is designed to give greater authority to those people responsible for the administration of the reef to enable them to police the regulations and to impose penalties in support of protecting the reef. That is why this Bill has the bipartisan support of the House and of the Parliament.

Dangers to the reef have been posed not by Australian citizens and not necessarily by development projects that may have been proposed in the past, but more particularly by foreign intrusion and foreign invasion of the reef by citizens from other countries. That is why this Bill is necessary. Firstly, it increases the penalties for poaching and for other violations of the reef. That is necessary, unfortunate though it may be, because while I believe that Australian fishermen and other Australian citizens who may conduct activities on the reef are conscious of the natural heritage with which they are dealing, unfortunately that same consciousness and the same determination to protect the natural environment have not been shown by citizens of other countries, particularly foreign fishermen who may from time to time visit the reef. It is necessary that adequate penalties be imposed to be able to protect the reef from such violation. This Bill does just that: it increases the penalties and it gives greater scope to officers of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to enforce those penalties by pursuing intruders beyond the normal boundaries of international law. But it also allows the expertise of the Marine Park Authority to be used for a much broader range of activities.

We are very conscious of the body of expertise that has been built up within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I compliment Mr Graeme Kelleher and the other scientific experts and marine biologists on his staff, who have, over the years with the breadth of their experience, established a very broad body of experience within the Marine Park Authority. It is pleasing to see that the Marine Park Authority wants to make that depth of experience available for use in other fields than simply the protection and development of the Great Barrier Reef. I compliment it on doing that. I hope that its experience can be used in a broad range of activities, particularly the protection of natural marine parks and natural environments in other waters around Australia. Hopefully its expertise can be made available to other areas of the world.

The Australian public is becoming increasingly conscious of that delicate balance between the natural environment, which we are beholden to protect for this generation and must pass on to future generations, and the demand for development. An intriguing debate is taking place in our community as to what is good, what might be best for the protection of the natural environment as against development for future generations. I do not think that this debate has ended: it will continue for some considerable time. The fact that it is taking place is good. I do not think any of us would presume that all development is good development. We must always be conscious of future generations and how best we can protect and pass on our environment and heritage to them. We must always accept that the Great Barrier Reef is one of those great natural heritages which we as Australians have been given the obligation of protecting, not just for future generations of Australians but also for the world.

I commend the management structure developed for the reef. I think that common sense has prevailed to develop for the Great Barrier Reef a structure where both State and Federal governments have been involved in putting together a management plan for the protection of a world heritage national park. This is the first time that such a management structure has been developed in Australia. It is a model that should be passed on for the protection and management of world heritage national parks everywhere. I compliment both the Fraser and the Queensland Bjelke-Petersen governments of that time on having the courage and the commonsense to combine their expertise to come up with such a management structure. It is also of great credit to the officers of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Queensland conservation authority that they were able to come together and cooperate on the protection of what all of us believe is a common heritage, and that is the Great Barrier Reef. What has developed from that is not a conflict between two levels of government but a cooperation between them to protect the Barrier Reef and provide a management plan for the future development of the reef. Credit should go to previous governments-the Fraser Government and the Bjelke-Petersen Government-and the officers of the authorities at both levels for being able to cooperate and develop such a plan and bring it together in the form of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

One of the continuing problems that the Authority faces-it will continue to be debated not only in the scientific community by marine biologists but also in the general Australian community, because it concerns all Australians-is the infestation of the crown-of-thorns starfish on the reef. Many Australians are a little bemused, if you like, or concerned because of the different scientific viewpoints and scientific evidence with which they are confronted. I think all Australian citizens would want to see the reef preserved for future generations. There is conflicting scientific evidence from so-called experts, some of whom believe that the crown-of-thorns starfish will despoil the reef forever, while others believe that it is a passing phenomenon, that it will not last for very long, and that the reef will eventually recover.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one quite knows.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Gwydir says, no-one knows. It is impossible for any so-called expert to be able to say conclusively that it will destroy the reef or that it is a passing phenomenon. As my colleague says, no-one knows. I am concerned that the Australian media, apparently for the purpose of instant headlines or instant sensationalism, presume to go to the Australian public and claim that the reef is being despoiled forever because of the infestation of the crown-of-thorns starfish. The media do not know that. They cannot be certain of that, just as the scientific experts cannot be certain of it. It is a great shame that a lot of emotion is being stirred up within the Australian community by a sensationalist media who do not know what they are talking about. It is most unfortunate that an expert body such as the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is prepared to take legal action for defamation against media organisations.
—They ought to clam up.

—I agree with my colleague; they should clam up. That is a most appropriate term. It is most unfortunate that sections of the media in Australia are prepared to go to such sensationalist lengths to make their story, because it is totally misleading. They do not know, because the scientific experts cannot be certain, what the long term impact of the crown-of-thorns starfish will be. I do not presume to be able to say what the long term effect will be because the marine biologists, the scientific experts, are not able to say. But as Australian citizens we have an obligation to allow the scientists, the marine biologists who are the experts in this field, to undertake their own scientific pursuits to their full extent before we start to draw conclusions.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that all those experts, irrespective of whether they are part of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, have one overriding ambition, and that is to protect the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park for the long term, to protect it for future generations and for mankind. In that we wish them well. However, although experts may have different views about the long term impact of the crown-of-thorns starfish, I do not believe that the long term benefit to the reef can be pursued by stirring up emotive sensationalism through the media. I condemn anyone who pursues that course of activity, because I do not believe that that is the best way to get action that will protect the reef in the longer term.

I am delighted that the Opposition supports the measure before us. We believe that the legislation is necessary to give officers of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority more authority to be able to pursue those people who may violate the marine park and its environs. We agree with the Government. Because the legislation seeks to protect one of our great natural heritages, which we all have a very keen interest in protecting for future generations, the Opposition is delighted to support it.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In summing up the second reading debate, I thank all honourable members who have participated in the debate. I suppose that, if one looks at what has happened in this House over the last month, one can see that this is one of the rare and happy occasions on which there seems to be total consensus. We have the fairly unique position of honourable members on both sides of the House being unanimous in their support for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: More important-and I think this bodes well for the future control of the Great Barrier Reef-is the fact that all members who spoke showed a genuine concern for the problems which clearly have to be tackled and approached. All were unanimous in the view that present and past Commonwealth governments and the Queensland State Government had reached a level of administrative consensus in respect of the reef.

Some honourable members indicated their concern about continuing pressure on the reef which will flow from increased tourism. The Great Barrier Reef is one of the great wonders of the world. It is true to say that the Government is dealing with the problem by introducing this legislation. A number of honourable members who have spoken in this debate indicated their concern about how one tackles the problem of the crown-of-thorns starfish. I would dearly love to assure the House, as I know my ministerial colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) would, that we have the scientific knowledge, that there is a consensus view and that we now have the procedures to resolve this problem. Debate resumed from 22 November, on the following paper presented by Mr Hawke:
Joint Defence Facilities-Ministerial Statement, 22 November 1988
and on the motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is resuming debate on a very important statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the joint defence facilities. This is the second such statement since the election of this Government in 1983. It is important because information about the joint facilities at Nurrungar and Pine Gap in particular-information about North West Cape was not included in this statement-is being revealed to the public. Indeed, very much more information is being made available than was ever envisaged or contemplated by previous governments right up to the election of this Government. This Government, in conjunction with our partner the United States of America, is determined to illuminate and enlighten the people of Australia in regard to the operation of these joint facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: These facilities are very important. As I said, they were clothed in great secrecy until the last few years. Unfortunately, this sent a lot of hares running and a lot of very factual material, basically from Des Ball, was put into the public arena. Some people made assumptions as to what the joint facilities were all about, and some of those assumptions were not 100 per cent correct, as is the case now. But one thing is absolutely certain: for the first time we have truly and-I think I can say-genuinely joint facilities. At the managerial end-that is at the hard end of the joint facilities; not just in the overall employment terms-we have a fairly substantial number of Australian personnel. In managerial and operational terms we are talking about 40 per cent of Australian personnel at Nurrungar and 30 per cent at Pine Gap. So overall we are looking at about one third, if not more, of Australian operational and managerial personnel at the joint facilities being Australian. That is very important, because of the functions that these joint facilities perform.

Nurrungar is a ground station which is used for controlling satellites in the United States defence support program. These satellites supply information about ballistic missiles, early warning, and other details that are related to missile launches, surveillance and the detonation of nuclear weapons. The surveillance role carried out at Nurrungar has been known for a very long time. Nurrungar plays a very important role in the arms verification area, in early warning and the whole disarmament regime.

Pine Gap, which is the other facility referred to in this statement, is a satellite ground station whose function is to collect intelligence data which supports the national security of both Australia and the United States. Of course, intelligence collected at Pine Gap contributes importantly to the verification of arms control and disarmament agreements. I chaired a subcommittee of this Parliament, the Subcommittee on Disarmament and Arms Control of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, for three years on the subject of disarmament and arms control. We reported in 1986. That report was distributed throughout Australia and was sent around the world. I think it was very well received by the United Nations (UN) and various other peace institutes. The report contained a lot of very useful information and this Government picked up many of its recommendations. Indeed, many of those recommendations were related to disarmament and the verification of many of the agreements. Verification is a particular problem and a discussion point among the superpowers and anyone interested in the disarmament regime. According to reports that have been made since the Prime Minister's statement, Pine Gap plays a very important role in respect of spying.

It is worth noting the political comments that have been made in the national press. Notably, Paul Kelly wrote an article in the Australian of 25 November in which he talked in very favourable terms about the Government's statement. He said, as I mentioned before, that the Government had brought forward many things that had not been available for public comment. We have talked about the agreement that we have had, the quite significant number of Australian personnel in the hard-nosed end of the operations. Thus we have joint facilities which are not only used for global operations and American interests but are also now used for Australian interests.

I turn to Geoff Kitney in the Australian Financial Review of 23 November when the headline was `Bases now spy for Australia'. It is quite an interesting change in public perceptions about the bases when even some people who were against the bases originally are now saying that if we are using them to spy for ourselves, if we are using them for our own intelligence, if we are using them for our own defence capabilities-which I will elaborate on in a minute-then it is okay. Indeed, it has been this Government that has moved in that direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a long way to go.

—The honourable member's party spent 30 years on that side doing nothing. In fact, for the last 20 years or so, when the joint facilities have been in place, we heard absolutely nothing. In fact, former Prime Ministers of this House, John Gorton and Billy McMahon, when they were Prime Ministers, did not even know what was happening there. In fact, many Prime Ministers did not know what was happening there and did not want to know what was happening there when the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) was a member of Australia's defence forces. It was only when this Government came into office that we demanded that we start to renegotiate. It was under this Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) that we renegotiated the leases and the terms of the lease, and it was under this Minister for Defence that this statement was able to be made last week by the Prime Minister. That would never have happened with the Opposition. The Opposition was `All the way with LBJ'-`Let us go to Vietnam!'
—What did your Prime Minister say 10 years ago?

—`We do not mind 500 young Australians being killed'-that was the coalition's policy. It was all right at the time. Australians have a different perception now but that was the Opposition's policy. It was `All the way with LBJ; don't ask questions'. What utter rubbish! The Opposition knows it would never have got the agreements we have got now. It knows it would never have got 30 per cent and 40 per cent of the hard-nosed personnel at the business end of the operation, because it would have caved in every time. All the old defence people on the coalition side of the House would come into defence debates time after time, changing Opposition defence policies every day, every week. The honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) came in and started sprouting about defence personnel, but the Opposition shuts up pretty quickly when one talks about defence housing, for example, or when I say the fact is that the Opposition was there for 30 years and it created the problem with defence housing, not the people on this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister's statement is very important and one that is significant in the sense, historically, that we have been able to go as far as we have. Obviously-and I think both sides of the House would agree-there are some things that we are unable to divulge and never will be able to divulge because of the intelligence aspect of the bases. They would be totally useless. Indeed, we hear criticisms from some people on the disarmament side. Senator Vallentine says, `No, let us have the bases under UN control'. That, of course, is absolute nonsense. Under UN control, there is no such thing as bases. We are looking at some fairyland, an Alice in Wonderland sort of thing that does not actually operate in the real world of politics. It would be all right to have it under UN control if all the other bases all around the globe had a similar situation. Of course, that is never going to occur. Indeed, these bases have a direct impact not only on the surveillance in regard to Nurrungar but, in the case of Pine Gap in regard to research and intelligence and not only on the US interests and globally but also on Australia's interest.

It is very significant that this Government has moved to put Australia's interests up front in regard to the joint facilities; that they are very genuinely joint facilities and we have a direct say in what happens, in what is collected, et cetera, at these bases. Indeed, we would argue on this side of the House that it is significant that it is in our interests to keep these bases and the Americans at these bases for quite some time to come.

As I said earlier, no-one could envisage, until 1983, when this Government came in, the information that this Government has now made public, because up until then it was all very hush hush and no one said anything about the facilities at all. I do not believe, apart from the very top secret intelligence, that is the way to go. The more people understand about the general aspects of what they do in the disarmament area and defence capability area for this country, the more people understand and believe they are very much desirable. That is something of which I am very proud. I believe the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, has done a magnificent job in regard to this magnificent statement before the House by the Prime Minister.

The statement will obviously be debated for some time but it has been received extraordinarily well, as shown by the press that it has received and the fact that we are moving not only to genuine joint facilities but also Australian operations, Australian control, Australian say in what is collected, what is proposed, et cetera. I think that is a very significant aspect of the statement by the Prime Minister, most of which, of course, was negotiated under the auspices of the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, over quite some time. That is about all I can say.

I support the statement by the Prime Minister. It goes a very long way to bringing the functions of the joint facilities to public debate, to the public arena and to the knowledge of the public. I hope there will be some more information let out. Mostly our American friends will not let it out, but I hope that in the not too distant future we can let out some more information. That in fact is in the public arena already. We can make that official and that will again, for the safety of Australia and debate and reception of these facilities, be very important for us all.

In summary, it was an important statement. It is a quantum leap forward. We have seen a magnificent leap forward to Australian control, increased interest at the hard-nose end, the business end of these facilities. We have seen an incorporation, shall we say, an interest in the Australianisation of these joint facilities for our purposes as well as those of the United States and the global interests of the Western world. That is something to be applauded. The Minister for Defence, who has negotiated this, should be applauded in this House. I support the statement by the Prime Minister.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Olympic Games: Tasmanian Gold Medallist-Unemployment-Immigration-Member for Throsby: Leadership of Delegation-Hansard Reporters-Australia Post-Prison System: South Australia-Unemployment: Logan City-Taxation

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being approximately 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday night I attended a function in the municipality of Clarence in my electorate for the sportswomen and sportsmen on the eastern shore. I sat opposite a very nice couple. Their names were John and Beverly Fysh. In discussion they said to me, `Bruce, do you know that our daughter is the only person from Tasmania who has ever won a gold medal at the Olympics?' I thought for a while and said, `Of course, she is'. I thought, `She has not got very much recognition'. Even though she was only an emergency for the hockey side, even though she did not participate in all the matches, she was still a gold medallist and the only Tasmanian-I note that she is a woman-who has ever won a gold medal. I thought that she deserves a bit of praise. That is what I intend to do for a couple of minutes tonight. First of all I want to congratulate her and congratulate her family. She is a local girl. She lives on the eastern shore of Hobart; she has lived there all her life. She attended the Rose Bay High School and then the Rosny Matriculation College. She is a very nice girl, held in very high esteem by everybody who knows her. I would like to pay my respects to her tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to give the municipality of Clarence, which has just become a city, a little bit of a prod. How about a civic reception for this girl, Tasmania's only gold medallist? Why do we not have a civic reception for her? Why do we not take her through the streets of Hobart. She is the only Tasmanian to have won a gold medal. It does not matter that she was a reserve. That means nothing. I know that my colleague the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) would agree with me that that is what we should do. I intend to take the matter a bit further when I go back and ask the new mayor of the City of Clarence to have a reception for her so that the people of Hobart can show their appreciation and their pride for a young lady who has become a gold medallist at the Olympic Games.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Premier?

—I think the Premier gave her a bit of a reception but I think he invited the nobs. I do not like all these nobs, because they go everywhere. I want a few of the ordinary people of my electorate to see her; and the ordinary people who know her-their friends and family-instead of some of those darned politicians who love to go everywhere and receive all the attention and glory. Thank God, I do not.

SPEECH.PARA: Back to the serious matter now. I know that my esteemed friend the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) will be saying a few words tonight so I will not get involved in that argument. The part of my electorate which now contains the Huon Forest Products company used to be the home of the apple industry. Now it has the highest unemployment of any area in my electorate. I inform the honourable member for Braddon that I read with dismay today that all the Federal Labor members of Parliament-I cannot remember their names because we never hear much about them; I know the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) is one who supports them-are saying no to the flitch mill. They are siding with the greenies, the conservationists, the people who get all the publicity in Tasmania. These are not the sensible, ordinary people who depend on the industry for their livelihood. Honourable members have the audacity and the hypocrisy-I use the word `hypocrisy' in the nice sense-to keep talking about unemployment and jobs, jobs, jobs. Here we have an opportunity. I notice that a reporter whose name is Darby-he might be a stringer for the Hobart Mercury-writes for the Sydney Morning Herald and he wrote an article with big headlines asking what we were doing to the forests in Tasmania. It is the same as the dams episode. Those on the mainland are killing us. People hope that they will win seats. However, the regrettable part is it is killing the ordinary, decent hardworking Tasmanians who depend on the industry for their livelihood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue I want to raise is a serious one which concerns the misleading of the Australian people by the Opposition in regard to immigration policy. Recently, we have had a few statements from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and other honourable members saying that the Opposition's statements earlier in the year were taken wrongly and were not promoting a racist immigration policy or one that was based on discrimination. The Opposition got away with that for a certain period. However, on Sunday, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), in an interview, clearly stated that, firstly, he had not been rebuked by John Howard for the comments that he had made earlier in the year in relation to Asian immigration and, furthermore, that he in fact stuck by those comments and did not resile from them. That is what he is saying at the end of November after the newspapers had reported that the Leader of the Opposition had in fact distanced the Party from the Sinclair position.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we now have? We have the Leader of the National Party saying that he does not resile from those comments. After the statement made by the Leader of the National Party on 12 August this year, the Leader of the Opposition issued a statement in which he said:
The impression created by the remarks of the National Party leader, Ian Sinclair, yesterday goes beyond the draft immigration policy to be considered by the Coalition Joint parties room.
I have told Mr Sinclair that.

That statement was interpreted universally as, in fact, Mr Howard rebuking the Leader of the National Party. The Canberra Times headed an article, `Immigration: Howard pulls Sinclair in'. What do we then find? Mr Sinclair said, in relation to that matter, that on neither occasion did John Howard rebuke him. When he was asked whether Mr Howard had issued an instruction that he not speak on immigration matters he said that no, he had not, and that that was not correct. He was asked by Kerry O'Brien:
Are you able to speak openly on immigration policy?
The Leader of the National Party replied:
Of course I can. I can speak openly on anything, Kerry.

This was despite what Mr Howard had given this House and the Australian people to understand, which was that it would only be the shadow Minister for immigration and himself who would be making comments on immigration. However, we then had Mr Sinclair saying that he had not resiled from his comments at all. He said that he had in no way resiled from remarks that he had made in Perth. He said that he did not see that it was necessary to keep on repeating things in which he believed. That is what Mr Sinclair said. For the benefit of the House I will repeat what he said on Sunday. He said:
What we are saying is that if there is any risk of undue build-up of Asians as against others in the community, then you need to control it.
He continued:

I certainly believe our policy says that. I certainly believe that at the moment we need to by changing the balance between skilled migrants and family reunions, reduce the number of Asians and encourage more migrants to fit within the overall balance of our Australian society.

What does the Leader of the Opposition have to say in relation to this very serious matter, given the fact that the Leader of the National Party as late as yesterday in the interview said that he did not resile from his comments, that he was entitled to speak on immigration matters and that he was entitled to speak on behalf of the National Party which was part of the coalition? What are we to believe in relation to the Opposition's position on this crucial question of discrimination in immigration policy?

I raise this matter because only a few days ago the Leader of the Opposition was objecting to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) having again raised the question of the discriminatory nature of Opposition immigration policy. The Leader of the Opposition says that the Prime Minister ought to get off this issue. However, the fact is that this issue is alive. The Opposition parties have to sort out their position. I call on them to do so. Mr Sinclair should clarify his position, as should Mr Howard, on this very important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on an article on page 3 of today's Sydney Morning Herald entitled, `Out of Africa: Hawke called in after clashes on MPs' tour'. The article was written by Pilita Clark and puts the position of the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), who was the leader of the parliamentary delegation of which I was a member and which visited Ethiopia, Tanzania, Mozambique and Zimbabwe in June and July of this year. As honourable members may have heard there has already been considerable talk around the Parliament about the difficulties encountered during this trip arising out of the bizarre behaviour of its leader. Unbeknowns to me, before we had even left Australia the honourable member for Throsby claimed that he had approached the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Duffy) to see whether action could be taken to stop my going on the trip. The Minister, as the article records, quite properly refused to have anything to do with his extraordinary requests. However the honourable member for Throsby clearly had it in for some of us before the trip had even started, and his campaign of extraordinary vindictiveness and distortion continues still. His version of what occurred during the trip as related in this article is so clearly at variance with the truth that some explanation is warranted.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, my wife's expenses for the trip did not come out of the taxpayer funding for the delegation. They were funded entirely out of my own pocket and entitlements, as the honourable member for Throsby would well know. Secondly, there were not numerous clashes between the leader and my wife, as he claims. The one incident that I do remember followed a meeting early in the trip with the Revolutionary Ethiopian Women's Association at Addis Ababa, after a particularly long session of haranguing by some revolutionary women's representatives about how the women of Ethiopia had been liberated since the `Glorious People's Revolution'. Supporting comments were made by the Government members of our delegation, including statements such as this nonsense.
I hope that you don't make the same mistake that we make in Australia where pregnant women are forced to have their babies in hospitals delivered by men under clinical conditions.

Throughout the whole of this my wife sat up at the back of the meeting, saying nothing and reacting to none of this, just as she had done throughout the whole trip. However, outside the building after the meeting she innocently quipped to a couple of us, in a quite innocuous and light-hearted manner, `Oh, you dreadful men, oppressing we women back in Australia'.

In an extraordinary display of overreaction, the honourable member for Throsby turned on her, swearing at her, and from then on set out to persecute her in every way possible for the remainder of the trip. He banned her from attending every official function in Mozambique, even though the host country expected her to be at the meetings and had a chair and place tag set out for her where it was appropriate. The honourable member for Throsby even resorted to inventing stories to prevent her from accompanying us on trips. For example, before we went to the African National Congress training college in Tanzania, mentioned in the newspaper article, he called me aside the morning before and told me that only two cars would be available for this excursion and that Margaret would have to stay behind, since there would be no room for her. When I checked this out I found we were taking two mini-buses and the government officials told me there would be tons of room. When confronted with this information, he immediately changed his story, saying he would not allow her to come anyway, on the ground that her name had not been previously forwarded to the training college. When I offered to ring them to ask if it would be all right for her to join us, he refused point blank, knowing they would have no objection. In fact, I checked with them the next day when we were there and was told that they would have been delighted to have had her along. His story was just a fabrication. Also, my wife did not `sulk in her room' following this incident, as the newspaper article claims, but spent the day with Swedish friends in Dar es Salaam and shopping in the city.
Our delegation leader did everything but lead. His behaviour was appalling and his use of four letter words beginning with `F' in front of women--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should not be casting aspersions on another member of the House. He can give his own opinions of what happened but I ask him to please stop short of casting aspersions on the leader of the delegation.

—My opinion is that his behaviour was an embarrassment to our country. He would introduce us all at the beginning of meetings as `comrades'. On occasions he would not even use the word `Labor' when giving his party affiliation--

—I take a point of order. It is customary that when an honourable member is attacking another member, he notifies that member. I hope that he has paid the honourable member for Throsby the courtesy of doing that.
—It is not actually a point of order; it is a point of courtesy.

—His attack on our delegation deputy leader, Bruce Goodluck, at Maputo Airport was possibly the worst incident of all, done as it was in full view of all the Mozambican Government officials. It is not true, as this article says, that our eating was done separately throughout the trip and embarrassed our hosts. This was never done at public functions and, when it was done in private, it was as much the choice of the honourable member for Throsby as it was ours. I believe he proved to be a most unsatisfactory and unprofessional person to lead a delegation. I hope that in future the Government will select someone more suitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise again the matter of the critical continuing shortage of Hansard reporters and the plight of their employment conditions. I raised this matter in the House on Thursday, 11 October, and I received letters on your behalf, Madam Speaker, in your absence, dated 20 October and 2 November. Whilst you recognised that the salary and conditions of Federal Hansard reporters were the lowest in Australia, notwithstanding that their hours of work were almost double those of the staff of most State Hansards, all you stated was that consideration would be given to the matters raised. Although that was the first occasion that I had raised the matter, I am informed that successive Presidents of the Hansard section of the Canberra Branch of the Australian Journalists Association have raised this matter with Hansard management over many years. Therefore, you will not be surprised to know that I, and the Hansard reporters, have little faith that these problems will be properly addressed on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: The casual engagement of interstate reporters from other Hansard staffs, who already enjoy higher salaries and better working conditions, was implemented as a short term solution when the present staffing difficulties first arose. This practice has now been in existence for some years and was no doubt considered by Hansard management to be the panacea to the critical shortage of reporters. This shortsighted, blinkered approach to staffing will undoubtedly lead to long term industrial problems, possibly as soon as tomorrow, when Hansard staff reporters attend a union meeting to discuss the perceived inaction by management in addressing staffing and other matters. Federal Hansard reporters have never previously engaged in industrial action which has resulted in industrial stoppages, but present staffing difficulties could result in their patience finally running out.

Since raising the matter with you in the House on 13 October, I have received unsolicited correspondence from both former and current Hansard reporters which not only confirms the gravity of the present situation but highlights the problems that have caused reporters to resign. As I have previously stated, it is a sad fact that hitherto loyal staff who have never engaged in industrial stoppages are now considering such action because of their continued dissatisfaction with inaction by Hansard management in regard to resolving these serious problems. It would appear that Hansard management is either unable to, or incapable of, resolving these longstanding issues. Accordingly, I urge that reporters' salaries and conditions, which are already well below those of other Hansards, be redressed immediately to avoid further resignations, occupational injuries, possible industrial action and the continued difficulty of attracting qualified competent reporters.

Having said that, I would now like to say a few words about the Australian Postal Commission. There was a great navigator by the name of George Vancouver who, I believe, was of special significance to Australia. It was through George Vancouver's activities that the west coast of Australia was largely explored. This led to the area around Albany being probably the best known part of Australia outside Sydney Harbour for many years. Australia Post, when approached to issue commemorative stamps to celebrate the bicentenary of Vancouver's discoveries, flatly refused. It said it was a matter of no great significance. One could easily say the same of Captain Cook. He discovered a small part of Australia and mapped the east coast-a matter of no great significance! Why it should be more significant on the east than on the west, I fail to understand.

Vancouver's activities probably forestalled the French and led to Australia being a continental nation. For had this not been so, we might now be sharing a country with another people, which would obviously lead to tensions that we do not presently have. One of the other important things that Vancouver did was to become very involved in the exploration of north-west Canada. A lot of people do not realise that this took place on his way from Australia. I believe it is outrageous that Australia Post is refusing to recognise the exploits of Vancouver. I will be talking more about this in the House at a later time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter that has special relevance to my electorate of Adelaide in that it contains the major part of South Australia's prison system, a system that is approaching crisis. For years now the Bannon Labor Government has presided over a chaotic situation. One of my State's major messes is the continuing row between the Government, the prison officers and the prisoners themselves. The cost of maintaining prisoners in South Australia's gaols has skyrocketed while the unrest grows even stronger.

SPEECH.PARA: The latest episode concerns two senior prison officers of longstanding, who have been made the subject of a police investigation of a prisoner's allegation. What is more, while under investigation the officers have been suspended from duty without pay. The matter has sparked discontent within the ranks of prison officers in the State, 400 of whom took to the streets of Adelaide last week to record their protest at what they consider to be a raw deal-and a raw deal it is, as I will explain. Already named in the press and the media are David Nash, Assistant Chief Correctional Officer, Grade 1, and Barry Smith, Senior Correctional Officer, who both worked at the Adelaide Remand Centre, known as the Arc, until 14 October, when they were stood down over allegations of assaulting a prisoner. The prisoner concerned was convicted of armed robbery, for which he was to serve seven to 10 years in Melbourne's notorious Pentridge Prison-an apprentice Ned Kelly who had made the same allegations a year ago, which were dismissed. The penalty of five days for the false allegations was added to his sentence.

It is a poor state of affairs when a proven perjurer, one of life's dregs, can cook up a story against two fine members of society who have the guts to do a job few of the rest of us would be prepared to do-I am referring to prison officers Nash and Smith-and get five days when he has been proven to be a liar and a fraud. Both men have been highly spoken of during the many years they have dedicated to serving the prison system. David Nash and Barry Smith are highly respected both within the Department and also amongst the criminals they have supervised. Both officers are members of the newly formed 600-strong Correctional Officers Association of South Australia (COASA). There is an ongoing and well-recorded feud between COASA and the Miscellaneous Workers Union (MWU) where prison officers are concerned. The MWU has a healthy number of seven such officers left amongst its membership, a fact that seems to upset South Australia's correctional services Minister, Frank Blevins, who is on the record as telling prison officers `You'll join whichever union I tell you to join'. This is a strange statement indeed but then those of us on the sane side of politics have often had difficulty understanding the confused workings of the socialist mind.

So the truth begins to emerge. Here we have a couple of loyal, long-serving and conscientious prison officers who have been used as pawns in a union power struggle and suspended without pay when a 10c pimp on a armed robbery charge makes an unsubstantiated allegation of assault. Precedent suggests suspension without pay is an extreme measure indeed but when we consider a previous incident involving the Manager, Assistant Manager and Movement Chief of the same institution we find that they were suspended with pay pending investigation of a similar allegation.

The 400 protesting prison officers say they are being screwed-no pun intended-by an unfair and unconstitutional system which disregards the maxim of `innocent until proven guilty'. How hypocritical is this? The rights of the prisoners at the remand centre are maintained while those that help in the maintenance of those prisoners' rights have their rights thrown to the wolves. The Department heavies had to search the State statutes long and hard before they came up with section 69 (1) of the Government's Management and Employment Act that allowed them to wreak their vengeance on these two fine officers. I suggest that the prisoner's allegations, when properly investigated by police as they are, will turn out be baseless mouthings as did the last such allegation from the same individual. Further, I suggest that prison officers Nash and Smith are being used as pawns in an ongoing union power struggle, conducted with the full blessing of a Minister in South Australia. In light of the fact that 400 prison officers took to the streets of Adelaide last week in support of their mistreated colleagues I submit that I am not the only one who thinks this way.

One prisoner in South Australia recently served less than one-third of his non-parole period through remissions gained by successive outbreaks of such industrial action which gave him a remission of four days of his sentence. As for the Minister for Correctional Services last week calling on me to apologise, I ask `What for?' Is it for having the courage to defend men and women who are daily performing this stressful and often dangerous task? What loss of dignity is there to prison officers when on duty they have to suffer the humiliation of sexual acts, simulated or not, being conducted through the medium of X-rated videos imported from Canberra or bought from a north-east video store? Since the local paper did not consider it necessary to get the facts and could not contact me I guess I will have to spoon-feed it with these facts as well as some startling information on drugs in prisons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss a commitment by my Government to Logan City. Much has been debated about Logan City and its very large unemployment problem. However, the situation has been exacerbated by the Logan City Council, which has rejected not one but two Federal Government grants totalling half a million dollars. Despite its rejection of such a grant aldermen on that council have requested consistently that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) visit the area and recognise that it is disadvantaged. However, the Government tends to act in a much more pragmatic and helpful way by giving grants to groups within the area that are seen to do work and are seen actually to address the needs of the area rather than the grandstanding which is currently being done by the Logan City Council. In this sense the Logan City community youth support scheme (CYSS) has been responsible for gathering $200,000 to develop a Skill-share program. This, I might add, has been at some great personal cost to the President of that CYSS, Mark Forrester, who has suffered an amount of personal abuse in the press and from the citizens of Logan City Council. Indeed, the Logan Council vilified him and when he approached the Trades and Labour Council for support for the unemployed in the area, the city council suggested that this was a further ploy by CYSS to get help. Of course it was a ploy to get help.

SPEECH.PARA: With more than 9,000 people unemployed in the area, it is incumbent upon us and our Government to attempt to redress the problem. That is exactly what the Logan CYSS was attempting to do when it made its application for Skill-share. The Trades and Labour Council supported us, as did the Logan City Chamber of Commerce. Both these groups are very much wiser and more humane than the good aldermen on the Logan City Council. Indeed, the $200,000 grant is now a testament to the work which Mark Forrester and his committee, the Trades and Labour Council and the Logan City Chamber of Commerce have done to ensure that the long term unemployed of Logan City will be helped. They will be helped not only by this $200,000 grant for the long term unemployed who are able to participate in training programs, but the Logan Chamber of Commerce has also gathered to itself a further grant of $300,000 from the Federal Government to assist in the stimulation of business in the area-a program for which the Logan City Council established its Economic Development Board, which to date has failed to attract any businesses whatsoever to the area. Indeed, this board has been seen by many as being simply a group of people who are more concerned about themselves and their own ends than with stimulating business in the area.

The Trades and Labour Council, the Chamber of Commerce and CYSS see the need to create an environment in which business can be stimulated, in which the long term unemployed can be assisted by retraining and in which there is a healthy business economy to ensure jobs and training for all in the area. I am delighted to be able to acknowledge our Government's commitment to that to the tune of $500,000 despite the fact that Logan City has a council which on the one hand has consistently rejected grants, and, on the other hand, publicly vilifies us for not helping that council. What is one to do with such people? Where do we go and where do we turn?

One can only hope that the business community and the long term unemployed within our area will acknowledge the source of their support, who is actually helping them and who has their best interests at heart. The Logan City CYSS has been very successful and has worked against considerable odds to get this grant to help people in our area, to ensure that training will be carried out and to ensure that the long time unemployed will find dignity through entering our economy. That also applies to the Logan City Chamber of Commerce, which hopes to stimulate business in the area. In the long term we all, as citizens of Logan City, will be a very much better and happier community despite the work which is not being done by the Logan City Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 October in this place I commented on the overly legalistic approach to tax matters by the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Trevor Boucher, and his officers, a point that was reiterated strongly in this place earlier today by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). While press reports in recent days indicate that Mr Boucher may be taking the continual criticism to heart and is to talk to the professional bodies concerned in the near future, I still receive many inquiries and criticisms from individuals about the activities of the Australian Taxation Office. Recently I received a letter from the Contractors Association in New South Wales which highlighted and exemplified the anger and frustration being generated by Australian Taxation Office perceptions and attitudes. With the indulgence of the House I will read from that letter. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our members and others are being terrorised by huge tax reassessments being issued by the ATO for periods of up to eight years. These figures, including 40 per cent penalties, 20 per cent interest and provisional tax demands, have reached as high as $186,000, quite enough to make the unfortunate recipient totally destitute. The ATO received the green light for their current actions with their success in the Tublikov case in 1984. IT 21.21 tax ruling widened the judgment considerably and the ruling itself is being widely interpreted by taxation officers to reassess small business men operating in the manner described above. What makes that action so terrifying for all Australians, not only the immediate victim, is that the assessments are retrospective, effectively making a crime something that was legal when performed.

In the short time available to me this evening it is not possible to explore these understandably emotive issues in more detail. However, it is clear that the Australian Taxation Office needs to modify its present generally overbearing, moralistic approach to tax assessment and revenue collection before the position degenerates further under the Big Brother syndrome.
